titleStmt.title: The woman-captain a comedy acted by His Royal Highnesses servants / written by Tho. Shadwell.
titleStmt.author: Shadwell, Thomas, 1642?-1692.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of original in Huntington Library.
Epilogue, spoken by Mrs. Berry, who acted the Woman-captain: p. [1] at end.

div.p: A COMEDY ACTED by His Royal Highnesses SERVANTS.
LONDON, Printed for Samuel Carr, at the King's-Head in St. Paul's Church-yard, 1680.

div.head: TO HENRY Lord OGLE, SON to his GRACE HENRY Duke of NEWCASTLE, &c.
div.p: THE great Obligations I received from my most Noble Patron, your illustrious Grandfather, and the favours conferred upon me by your Excellent Father (amongst which, I can think none greater than his recommending me to your Lordships Kindness and Protection) have engaged me to make this acknowledgment of my Duty to your Lordship; and to beg that you will own me, and defend this Comedy. I hope I shall, hereafter, be able to present you with something more worthy your Acceptance; but let this suffice to give you a title to me, and all my endeavors, which, as often as I can, shall be employ'd to serve you.

Had you not been obliged by the commands of your Father to favour and protect me; yet, from you I should have hop'd to have found Patronage; for the great Love which you have for Arts and Sciences, which would have made you cherish my endeavors towards them: By this inclination you give us early proofs of your inheriting the Vertues of your Ancestors, as you are like to do their Fortunes; which with the great accession by your Match with the Noble and Renowned Family of the Piercies, will make your Lordship the greatest Subject of England. And, by your early Vertues, you give all, that know you, hopes that you will be able to maintain that Character, by all the qualities that become a great Man: And, from the two Noble Stocks of Cavendish and Piercy, Posterity is like
to see a race of true▪, and not Romantick Heroes, who may serve their Prince virtuously, and that way oblige their Countrey as we doubt not but your Lordship will.

My Lord, it has been the custom of Dedicators of late to make the Praises they give to their Patrons so▪ extravagant, that they become Abuses, and therefore I am loath to say what I think: only one virtue of your Lordships I am too much pleas'd with not to mention; which is, that in this Age, when Learning is grown contemptible to those who ought most to advance it, and Greek and Latin Sence is despised, and French and English Nonsence applauded, when the ancient Nobility and Gentry of England, who not long since were famous for their Learning, have now sent into the World a certain kind of spurious brood of illiterate and degenerous Youth, your Lordship dares love Books, and labour to have Learning. And may your Lordship go on in this virtuous race you have begun, that so you may be a Protection to your Servants, a Consolation to your Friends, and an Honour to your Countrey; which is the hearty Wish of

closer.signed: Your Lordships most Obedient humble Servant Tho. Shadwell.

lg.l: LOrd! how the Poets in these times will pine,
For solid Dulness they must all design,
When Wit won't sell, and they shall lose French Wine.
And what can Players hope for in these days,
When e'r the Idle Youth forsake our Plays.
The empty Head, that never thought before
But on New fashions, or a fresh new Whore:
Who, without us, no Afternoon could spend,
Nor shew Himself, nor meet a secret Friend,
Whom mounting from the Pit we use to see
(For dangerous Intrigues) to'th' Gallery.
Where stead of Maidenheads 'tis oft his hap
By bold advent'ring to atchieve a Clap,
Or down he comes, and lolls i'th Orange-wenches lap.
For News he now walks gravely up and down,
And every Fop's a Politician grown,
Instead of—
Pox here's no Company, let's to White-hall,
Or to the Park, or where is there a Ball?
What News! ha'ye been at Westminster to day?
How move the French? what do the great Ones say?
Things go not well, we wish we know not what;
But there are some can tell, we're sure of that:
With Politick shrug, and notable wise Look,
They censure Councels, who ne'r read a Book.
The Citt, who with his Wife and hopeful Son
Would come t' a merry Play, now all does shun,
And on the Guard learns to let off a Gun.
Others their Shops and precious Wares neglect,
With their wise Heads the Nation to protect:
Ev'n Bulks all day of Tenants are bereft;
For News stitching, and singing Psalms are left.
Each Coffee-house is fill d with subtle folk,
Who wisely talk, and politickly smoke.
To them whose Right it is, leave Government▪
And come to us, we'll give you all content:
Full Theatres, 〈◊〉 overflowing Nile,
Shew Peace and Plenty in this happy Isle.
The Nation's weather-glass a Play-house is,
And when we thrive, you never do amiss.
Fear not that we'll offend you with much wit,
This day we promise you shall quiet sit,
And have a Play for men of business fit:
And though you cruelly should Damn that Play,
I'll hang, if I don't make you laugh to day.

list.item: Sir Humphrey Scattergood, A Prodigal, Extravagant, and Luxurious Knight.
Gripe. A miserable Wretch, that denies himself all Necessaries, very Jealous of his Wife.
Sir Christopher Swash, A foolish Debauched hot-headed Fellow, always Drinking and Scowring, desirous to be thought a mad Fellow.
Heildebrand, Two Bullies, followers of Sir Christopher.
Blunderbus, Two Bullies, followers of Sir Christopher.
Sir Nich. Peakgoose, A sneaking Cully, nosed by a Whore.
Mrs. Gripe, Gripe's Wife, the Woman-Captain.
Bawd, Fool, High-Constable, Constable, Watch, Servants, Market-Women, Apprentices, Parson, Soldiers, &c.

div.head: ACT. I.
div.stage: Enter Sir Humphrey Scattergood dressing, Steward and Fool, with a number of old Servants.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.p: GOod your Worship! Turn us not away. I liv'd with my old Master Thirty years and upwards.

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.p: And I fifty.

sp.speaker: Sir Hump.
sp.p: Yes! he lov'd an old-fashion'd block-headed greasy Servingman, whose Cloaths were died with Drippings of March Beer, and whose Beards stunk of Beef and Brewis, and his Breath like the fume of an Alms-Tub.

sp.speaker: 3 Serv.
sp.p: We are all old, and have liv'd a long time here.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Ye have the more reason to go away now, you are pursy, lazy, clumsy Rogues; The time my Father's will requir'd you to be here is out. This is my happy Day of four and twenty, till which long time my Father's Will kept me from my Estate. I now discard ye all; now I'll be Master, I have provided a set of French▪ fellows to serve me; they are fit for Service.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: They are for Slavery, They are born and bred to it: But it was never good time since English Fools were serv'd by French Rogues.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Hey! Dubois! give 'em 40 s. a piece to drink, and send 'em packing.

sp.speaker: Servants.
sp.p: Good my Lord, We beseech your Lordship.—

sp.speaker: Dubois.
sp.p: Wait without!
sp.stage: [Ex. all, but Steward and Fool. Sir Hum & Valet de Chambre.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: How now, why stays that Fool?

sp.speaker: Fool▪
sp.p: Because that Fool has more wit than to go away.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Sirrah! begon! I will not keep you.—

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Some body I see has us'd wicked Court Policy to supplant me in my employment.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: he's keep no Fool, tis out of fashion for great Men to keep Fools.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Because now adays they are their own Fools, and so save Charges: But for all that they delight in Fools out of Livery. When do you see any of em favour a Wit?

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: I'll have none, 'tis exploded ev'n upon the Stage.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: But for all that Shakespear's Fools had more Wit than any of the Wits and Criticks now adays: Well, if the History of Fools were written, the whole Kingdom would not contain the Library; yet a vast number of Fools have been in Print, and written their own Histories.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: You are a Satyrical Fool, and will give offence.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Indeed this Age is not able to bear Satyr; and yet 'tis a very laughing jeering age: all Fools laugh at one another, and scarce any one is such a Fool, but he has a sub-Fool that he can laugh at—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Begon Sirrah! I'll have no fooling.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Good Sir Humphrey, I will be a fashionable Fool, and learn to lisp, speak French, and be very much affected. I will be a wellbred Fool, a Flatterer, or a Pimp, if you please, you may turn away a Knave or a Chaplain for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Who waits there! take away the Fool!
Well, Mr. Steward, upon condition you will leave off your miserable 〈◊〉 and follow my Instructions, I receive you agen▪

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Since it must be▪ I'll endeavour to obey you in all.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Put some Pulvilio into my Peruke! give me some Tuberose. You old Fool reach some Orange-Flower water for my Handkerchief, how do you like this!

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: I dare not tell you▪
I'll give you leave▪

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Methinks! it is unmanly to keep such a stir about ones Body, I'd rather be embalm'd, like an Aegyptian body, once for all, and make no more trouble of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Thou dost not consider what a stinking Animal man is, exceeding all Beasts in stinking, and wouldst thou not have one mollifie these Natural imperfections—

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: I would have you cleanly, and serve God as my old Mr. did; sure your Worship does not consider—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Yes fool— I do nothing but consider how I may please every sense, I have. They were not given me in vain. No— all my study shall be bent to find variety of Delights, and when my own too barren fancy stops, I'll have a Council wittier than Nero's, to invent new Pleasures.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Good morrow to my Lord of Land and Timber! long may'st thou live and flourish in thy pleasures. The happy day is now arriv'd that makes thee Master of thy Acres, and thy self.

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: A Thousand Joys fall on you. The Slavery you did endure under your wretched Father, will make you relish the Liberty you now arrive at.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: And I will use it to the full! nor Land nor Sea shall bound my pleasures— what e'r the Globe affords I'll have to satisfie my Luxury.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Virtuously resolved.

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: Joy of my heart: go on.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: I Married one young fond fool, and broke her heart already; But now I keep a Whore, or Whores.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Yes, all the Parish from fifteen to five and thirty.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Virtuous still.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Excellent Councellors for the speedy confounding of an Estate.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: You that were my Father's good old Steward, and are my formal Coxcomb: I have taken a new course, and so must you: I'll not be serv'd so nastily as in my days of Nonage, or as my Father was; as if his Meat had been dress'd at Pye-Corner, by greasy Scullions there. His boyl'd meat, a little Mutton with a sprig of Rosemary, and a vast deal of lean Oatmeal Pottage.

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: And Mutton roasted as if it were prescrib'd for the Pox, and of huge Leicestershire pease-fed Sheep, as rank as old He-Goats, and the Poultry died all of Hectick Feavers.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And Sallets wither'd, the fruit Crab apples, Sweetings and Horse Plumbs; and for Confections, a few Carraways in a small Sawcer, as if his Worship's House had been a Lowsie Inn.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Then three or four monstrous Olives, with a spoonsul or two of damnable sharp Capers, and Suffolk Cheese.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: These things my good old Master was pleas'd with, or he had not so increas'd his Wealth.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: He did well: and I will revel now with what he left. Choak not me with your Providence with a Pox to you—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Wou'd you feed my Lord like a Country Justice of 300 l. a year, that has no gusto?—

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: Or like a Lawyer in Ram-Alley, or Attorneys joyning their 6 d. a piece at a greasy Cooks.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That for their Suppers score their penyworth of Tallow-cheese at a Chandlers, with every one his Jug and Pipe of Mundungus.—

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Be pleas'd to instruct me, and I shall obey.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: My chief Cook has a Book drawn up by these Gentlemen, and my self: Read and be learned.— There you shall find what is in season still— the youngest Meat always most nourishing.— The new faln Lamb. The tender Kid, and young fat Pigs. Veals fed with Milk, Whitebread, and new-laid Eggs, with young fat Beefs, and smallest Forrest Mutton, fat Bucks for Summer, Barren Does for Winter.

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: Fawns out of their Dams Bellies ript, Gelt Goats, Bruis'd Venison, Sucking Rabbits, Leverets, Dousets, White Haws, Velvet Head and Ears, Shoulders of Venison in the Kell with blood.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Turkeys, Pea-Hens, Pullets, Capons, Ducks, with Geese so cramb'd as to be drown'd in fát; squab Pidgeons, Chickens in the Grease, fat Swans, and Barn-dore Hens— with cluster'd Eggs, that are provocative.—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: The young plump Partridge, with the tender Powt; The Pheasant and the Quail, the Rail and Plover, roasted with the blood in 'em.

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: The mounting Lark, the Messenger of Day, the long bill'd Cock, that Winter brings in Mists-with Snipe, Duck, Teal, the Curlew and the Wild-goose, the Brant-goose, Solon-goose and Puffin.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Young Rooks, and new hatch't Martins, the Black-bird, Felfare, Thrush and Wheat-Ear, which far excels the Roman Beca fica.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Lincolnshire Fowl that's fatted with sweet Curds; as Pewits, Dottrils, Gulls, Knats, Ruffs and Reeves. All these I have had, and you must now provide.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: All this shall be done, and your Worship undone.—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: And then for Fish what the vast Seas afford, Ponds, Immense Lakes and Rivers too! Brett, Mullet, Turbet, Smelt, Plaice, Seate, Cod-whiting, and the old Organ Ling with gold Flakes, with heightning Sturgeon to stir up my blood▪ provoking Oisters, and the lusty Lobster: Crabs, Shrimps, Crafish Pottage, Muscles and Cookles, and dissolved Pearl and Amber in my sawce▪

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: The Luscio, Eel, the Trout, Char Tench, Perch, calverd Salmon▪ And from the Ponds, over grown Pikes, Carps, Breams, Torecells. The German Fish as fat as Bucks in August.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: And when I would cocker up my self, Rams-Cods, Lambstones, Bucks, Dowsets, Sparrows, Brains, the spawn of Fish, flakes of piled butter'd Eggs with Ambergreece; and when my taste grows Wanton, I will feed on Mushroons, and on Frogs, and have a race of large Italian Snails, young Tortoises drest costly in their shells, and Squirrels flesh, which is dissolved Nuts, and the Indian Birds-Nest mollifi'd in Broath.

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: Then Virmicelti, Potato and Tartonphily, and slatulent Roots to stir up and to enable Appetite.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: I should have taken these hard Words for conjuring, but why must your Worship have French Cooks. Methinks my Masters old English Cookmaid, with good store of Parsley and Butter, did very well.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Away you Coxcomb: Let it be your care to keep my Cellar always full as it is now.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: I am acquainted with my old Master's Merchant, he us'd to let him have very good Langoon and Burdeaux.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Porters and Carriers shall drink that; I'll have Vin d' aye, high Country Wine, Frontiniac; all the delicious Wines of Italy and Spain; the richer Wines of Greece and Sicily.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And Celery, Champaign and Burgundy, with Vin de Bon, Vin Celestine, and Hermitage, and all the Wines upon the fruitful Rhine.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: When I debauch, the Yeoman of my Wine cellar, dre'st like God Bacchus, squeezes his twined Wreaths of Grapes upon us— And we have floods of this Poetick Juyce.: But do you hear, Steward, I must have Whores in abundance; see you provide a world of Strumpets.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Does not your Worship mistake me? I am your Steward.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Yes, to provide me all things necessary; and are any things so necessary as Whores. I say, let me have Whores innumerable, and let it be your special care— That every Gentleman that comes within these Walls may have his Cher entirè▪

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Your Worship has a Mistress, I dare not call her Whore—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: I keep one high, because it is the fashion; But for my use I'll have as many Whores as mortal man can turn himself to.

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: Live, live! my Noble Knight, and be Immortal—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Push Nature on, my Friend, and live apace.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Hee'l soon be at his Journeys end; But the chief Material is wanting ready Money, I understand the Cash your Father left is flown, to pay in part your Debts.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Go to Gripe, my foolish Kinsman the Usurer. That is such an Ass to deny all his Sences, to live miserably to dye rich: Take 10000 l. and let him have a Mortgage till I cut down Timber to redeem my dirt— begon—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This damn'd Usurer has a pretty Wife, I have a devillish mind to her; but she's kept so close, though I have gone to borrow Money when I have had no need on't, I cannot get access to her; the Rogue suspects every Male, from a Prince to a Kitchin▪ Boy.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: She's so pretty on my Conscience, none would refuse her; I have set snares for her, she can never be seen but out of a Window, which is no bigger than the hole of a Pillory.

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: He locks her up, and always carries the Key about him.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Nay, at Night he sows his Shirt and her Smock together, that upon any violent motion the twitch may wake him: There's a Horn-preventing Design.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Faith, that shall not do, his jealousie shall pimp for me. Let us but wait upon you in a visit to him, and let us alone.

sp.speaker: Footm.
sp.p: An't please your Honour, yonder is a reverend fat old Gentlewoman desires to be admitted.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Bring her in: a Bawd I warrant you.
Oh honest Bawd! How dost thou do?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Do! why I am e'n worn out in your Worships Service; I have gotten a hoarseness will never leave me, with rising a Nights, to let in your Worship, and your unseasonable Company to save my Windows: Well, I cannot live long.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Thou wilt dye nobly then, in the Service of thy Countrey.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Nay, Heaven be prais'd, I have been diligent in my Calling, very diligent to supply the Necessities of young Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: What a despicable thing a Bawd is! I hate 'em with my Heart, filthy Creatures.

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: They are something filthy;— But they are necessary, very necessary.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Poor Bawds are carted, while great Mens Pimps are Company for Lords!

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: I have no less than three Maiden-heads upon my hands, I have agreed with their Mothers, who truly are careful honest Parents, and love to provide for their Children with a Motherly affection. I shall have 'em cheap, considering the rarity of Maiden-heads in this Town. I thought to give your Worship notice, if you have use for one of 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: For one! Ownds! I'll have 'em all. I'll spare no Money. Let me have 'em to Morrow, or to Night; for fear they should not keep.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: I cannot have 'em till to Morrow, I fear.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If so— then let us have a Bevy of Whores for a rank Ball, for we intend to be luxurious to Night.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: It shall be done: But I am almost faint with running up and down, and taking pains.—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Let her be taken in and rub'd and cawdled, as the Good Wives use the Phanatick Labourers in the Gospel; and let the Bawd have Sack enough.

sp.speaker: Footm.
sp.p: It shall be done: yonder are Milleners, Periwigg-men and Perfumers, and Tradesmen of all sorts waiting without.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Bid my Steward and Valet de Chambre dispatch 'em; I hate Business: Now let us revel, this Day I dedicate to all my Senses; I'il Feast 'em all after we have Dln'd with all the Luxury Wit can invent, with choicest Musick, and the best of Women—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Whores, you mean.

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: Ay, ay! What use can we make of honest Women?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: None: They are as bad as Drones in a Hive.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Whores I do mean: With whom after we have Danc'd and Toy'd— I'll have my Baths prepared full of most fragrant Scents. Where we will play and wanton with our Concubines; there we ll lye soaking till we be refreshed. Then we'll come out, be rub'd, and be anointed with precious Oyls and Essences; and then we'll roll our selves in Beds of Orange-Flowers.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How I dissolve at the Description.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I am all Extasie already.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Oh, here's my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: We come to with you Joy, my dear Lord, of this happy Day.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Ye bring it with you! Gentlemen, salute these fair Ladies.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Are these Friends of your Mistress, Whores?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: If they be, as a hundred to one they are, They are glorious ones!

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Fy, fy, Whores! That's a naughty word. They are Ladies; there are no Whores but such as are poor and beat Hemp, and Whipt by Rogues in Blew Coats.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: They are brave Magistrates to commit Adultery themselves, and whip poor Wenches for simple Fornication.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: There's no Law to whip but that of Vagrants, and when a poor Wench has laboured in her Calling seven years in the same Parish; These Fellows will whip her for a Vagrant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: These old Fellows, that love it themselves, think the Wenches do so too, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: You are the pattern of all Knights; you keep your Mistress so fine; I'll swear 'tis very commendable—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Oh 'tis admirable! all the Town admires you: You win the Hearts of all the Ladies with it, I vow.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: No! we must all yield to your Friend Sir Nicholas Peakgoose: He is the most liberal and most obsequious Keeper, and starves his Wife and Children for you.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: I must confess he does pretty well.—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Why did you not bring him hither?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: I should be willing enough; but if I use him to't, he'll be always going abroad in my Coach with me: No! that must not be.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: She has a rare hand over him; if I could govern my Gallant so, I were a Princess.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: I desire not to govern, my Dear; if I have but thy Love, Child, I wish for nothing else— But thy Money.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: No more! No more! Call in my Musick, and let 'em Sing and Play— Come in.

lg.l: LOve thee till there shall be an end of matter,
So long, till Courtiers leave in Courts to flatter;
While empty Courtlings shall laugh, jeer, and jibe,
Or till an old lean▪ Judge refuse a Bribe.
Till Young'men Women bate, I will love thee;
Till greedy Lawyers shall renounce a Fee,
And till Decrepit Misers Money hate,
Or Statesmen leave to juggle in a State.
While Priests Ambition troubles Common-wealths,
Till Whores grow chaste and Thieves forsake their Stealths;
Till Tradesmen leave to Cozen and to Lye,
Till there's a Worthy Flatt'rer, or Brave Spie.
Till Honest Valiant Men can be afraid,
Till Kings by Favourites are not betray'd;
Till all Impossibles do meet in one,
I'll love thee Phillis, and love thee alone.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Now let us retire and take the Pleasure of our Gardens: Musick follow us—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Come Richard, because thou art but new come, I must instruct thee— Thou see'st my whole Design is to be Rich.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Yes, and to keep your Servants Poor.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: And to that end, I deny and keep my base unruly Senses under: for if any one sense get the better of a man; he'll ne'r be rich.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I am sure I han't pleas'd one since I came.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: That's well: Let me have three Ribs of Mutton boil'd in a Pipkin for our Dinners; go, buy me a lean Breast— lean meat is wholsomest.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: If I could light of a Sheep that dy'd in a Ditch.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Ay, that should be cheap— besides, I like a Natural Death better than Murder. To Morrow is Holy day— I will have four Ribs, and some Cabbage.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: This is feasting, but our ordinary Diet of Oatmeal and Water—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: 'Tis very wholsom and cleansing—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: 'Tis the Scotch-Diet, very good for Mangy Hounds; What Sawce will you have for your Mutton?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: A Pox on Sawce! it spoils the Natural appetite; yet some Onion or Garlick you may get: I have some Ferkin'Butter and Suffolk Cheese, fine lean Cheese, twill go so far—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Sir, I have a great Inclination to a 〈◊〉 〈◊〉▪ May I not get one? 'tis cheap—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Not so cheap, yet next Holy-day I will buy one for my Family: But Ox Livers and the Entrails of 〈◊〉, are very nourishing.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: He cannot be content to rob and oppress men with his Extortion, but he must rob the Dogs of their diet; you 〈◊〉 Kids and Lambs of your own, if it please your Worship.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: It does not please my Worship, sure you have liv'd with some Epicure: No, sell 'em to Luxurious fools, that will die Beggars.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I hear Sir Humphrey Scattergood intends to send a Buck.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I'll sell it then; 'twill cost more the Baking than 'tis worth— we kill our selves in England with filthy pampering.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I can go a Fowling with my Peice, and catch Wild-fowl for your Worship.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: By my troth but your Worship shall not; you will spend more in Powder and Shot than your Bodie's worth; Besides, a water-Spaniel with his ravenous gut will eat me out of house and home: Wild-fowl? They are fit for Lucullus or Apicius.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Sir, we can steal Coneys, if it please you—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: No Sir! I must find you Butter. What damn'd Luxurious Fellow hast thou lived with?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you be pleas'd to let us have some Wheat Bread, for I have gotten the Griping, and the Iliaca Passio, with Rye and Barley Bread.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Peace Fool! I am not so Prodigal, thank Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Must we never have any Wine or Strong— Beer—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Why! you Impudent fellow, would you have us dye of Feavers? To drink Wine shall be Treason, and strong Beer Felony without Clergy: I have wholsom very, very small Beer, so clear, so fine, the Mault not to be tasted in't— The Patriarchs drank nothing but Water.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: That I deny, ask Lot else▪

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Go— Unlock my Wife's Chamber, and bid her come to me▪ This damn'd pampering Rogue would ruin me with his Gut.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Will this Tyrannie never be at an end? must I be always thus abridg'd of Liberty? a ●…am▪ d Fowl has a better time on't, for that's fed well; but I am coop'd up and starved▪ nay have no Necessary of life, that's fit for a young Woman—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Come Love, you have very good wholsom food, 'tis fit a young Woman should mortifie and keep down her Lusts.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Especially when she marries an old Man, hee'l fast her down to his own appetite—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Nay, in the Winter I am kept without Fire or Candle. I have neither Natural or Artificial heat from—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: 'Tis to preserve thy life, my Love. Didst thou ever see Cooks or Glassmen long liv'd? Fire destroys the Natural heat, they live longest in cold Countreys.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Yet Meat is always raw for want of fire.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I will save fire, and have it roasted by Burning▪ Glasses; and instead of Candles (and by the way the Grand Signior, suffers none of his Wives to have any,) I will have Glow-worms, rotten Wood and fish Bones— Fire suffocates Natural heat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I have heard your Servants in Winter wish for the Plague or any hot Disease; and I for my part could be contented with a Feaver.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Can you not use Exercise to stir up your Natural heat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: You let me have Exercise little enough! Heav'n knows.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Can you not play at Shuttlecock, or carry a Handful upon occasion?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I will play at Stool-ball with the Maids, and that will stir up Natural heat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: No— I have endured your cruel Tyranny too long; but above all, your Jealousie is most provoking.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: 'Tis nothing but my love, my great love. Dost thou think I do not love my Money— why I am Jealous of that, and lock it up as I do thee— I know what a Treasure thou art▪

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Give me leave to know my own value too: And that I deserve not to be used so, I will have the liberty of a She-Subject of England.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: What a Pox! The liberty of Cuckolding your Husband, for that it comes to, to receive Visits, and sculk about in Chairs in Vizors, to meet damn'd Roguy Whoremasters, which they call Admirers with a Pox to 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Thou deserv'st to be used so. When you are at home I am never out of my Prison, but in your presence, my cruel Jailor; and when you are abroad, I am fed at a Grate like the Lyons in the Tower (if I may call it feeding.) If there be any means under the Sun to get my liberty, I will attempt it.
Nay then I will use my Conjugal authority.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Sir Humphrey Scattergood's Steward is come to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Go into your Chamber! go, I say.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Well Tyrant, I shall be quit with you.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: No, you shall not; I'll take care not to be a Cuckold.

div.stage: [She goes, he follows her, lock's her in, and returns.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Sir, I am your Friend and Servant to command. Mr. Gripe, Good Morrow to your Worship.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Mr. Steward, What brings you hither.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: My Master's Command.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: What can his Worship honour me withal?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: It is to borrow Money on a Mortgage.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Looke you Richard, this is an Ass that will please all his Senses, and he must borrow▪ Oh damn'd Senses! Well, the Money's ready, 10000 l. we treated for.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: E're long we shall have occasion to trouble you for more, as Sir Humphrey goes on.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: See what becomes of foolish Sense-pleasers! Poor Puppies! Miserable▪ Fools! I pity 'em: I'll not please one, not I▪ Richard: Come, let's about this Business, and get my Lord to Seal.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Well said, old Chaucer, say I.—

lg.l: 'Twould make one▪ scratch where it does not itch,
To see Fools live poor to dye rich.

div.trailer: The End of the First Act.

div.head: ACT. II.
div.stage: Enter Sir Humphry, Bellamy, Wildman, Phillis, Celia, Chloris. Servants waiting at Dinner.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: CAll in my Musick! I'll consecrate my Birth-Day to all my Senses: He is a narrow-hearted Ass that pleases one at once; I'll please as many as I can together.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It is Ingenious Luxury!

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: I hate a mere Glutton, a mere Drunkard, or a meer Wencher; They are as bad as meer Scholars or meer Lawyers, good for nothing else: That man is happiest that takes delight in most things: There's not a Virtue or a Vice I'll leave untry'd for Pleasure or for Curiosity.

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: There spoke a Cherub; Fill up the Bowl then, fill it high; fill all the Glasses up; for why, here's our noble Friend's, Sir Humphrey's Health.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Give me a Brimmer to celebrate his Birth-day. Ladies, There's no scaping this Health. Men of Rosin and Cats-guts, strike up.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Strike up! D' hear Rascals! Let me have costlier Scents, and fume the Room; my Nostrils are not pleas'd enough.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Are all ready? a Thousand years to you.

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: And all the while the joy of Wine, Youth, and Beauty with you.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Thy everlasting Health, my Dear!
sp.stage: [Sound an Alarm all together. They flourish.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: My Lord, Mr. Gripe has drawn Bills; they are accepted, and he is come to have you Sign and Seal—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Kick that old Fool out, is he come to interupt my pleasure with damn'd confounded Business? which always must with me give way to my delight.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: How this must rejoyce my old Master's Ghost, cou'd he but see it!

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Good! How fast his Worships Land will melt into my Coffers; these are foolish Sense-pleasers, Richard.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Sit down and eat with us, Mr. Gripe.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I will not eat luxurious Meats: I love no Surfeits.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Give him a Beer Glass to Sir Humphrey's Health.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I have renounced Wine, I do not care for Feavers, nor will I please one Sense I have.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Out on him! Filthy fellow▪ will he not please his Senses?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Methinks a Feaver should be a very pleasant Disease for an old Man.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Are you mad Sir! why 'twill cost you nothing; at least give me leave to snap at a little Meat and Wine.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: You Rascal! will you Disgrace my House-keeping. They'l think y'are Hungerstarv'd—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: They'l not think much amiss.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Peace you damn'd Epigram! contein your self, or I will mawl your Pate for you: Laugh at these Sense▪ pleasers; They will dye in Ditches, fool.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.p: Better dye than live in Ditches, and we live worse— for Frogs have a better life than we.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Let us not mind this Brute. But let your Servants Dance their Entry you promis'd—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Let 'em begin!
Does not this please you?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: What is the worth of any thing, but so much Money as 'twill bring: He was a brave Poet that wrote that.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: But here are fine Ladies! here's a sight for you, and to enjoy 'em in Dalliance, were pleasure infinite—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: A huge Trunk-full of Bonds and Mortgages, and another great Coffer-full of Money to rowl and wanton in; There's a sight! there's rapture for you—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Yes, for Fools that make Money the end of their wishes, and not the means to other things. Come on! Sing the Song I love so well—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Pox on Songs! give me the Jingling of Money-bags.

lg.l: LEt some great joys pretend to find
In empty Whimsies of the mind;
And nothing to the Soul can come,
Till th' ushering Senses make it room.
Nor can the Mind be e'r at ease,
Unless you first the Body please.
Life is, what e're 〈◊〉 Man may doubt,
But taking in and putting out.
Since Life's but a Span,
Live as much as you can:
Let none of it pass without Pleasure;
But push on your Strength
Of what Life wants in length:
In the Breadth you must make up the Measure.
All solid Pleasures, Fops lay by;
And seek they know not what, nor why:
Imperfect Images th' enjoy,
Which Fancy makes, and can deftroy.
Wh' in immaterial things delight,
Dream in the Day as well as Night:
In that how can they Pleasure take,
Of which no Image Thought can make.
Since Life's, &c.
In vain no moment then be spent,
Fill up the little Life that's lent;
Feasts, Musick, Wine the Day possess;
The Night, Love, Youth and Beauty bless.
The Senses now in parcels treat,
Then all together by the great;
No empty space in Life be found,
But one continued Joy go round.
Since Life's, &c.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Very fine, I vow—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Upon my word 'tis delicate!

sp.speaker: Chl.
sp.p: Well, Sir Humphrey's a sweet man.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: How do you like this, Mr. Gripe?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: 'Tis abominable, profane, scandalous, and scurvy.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: I'll try to please you; you shall hear an Italian Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I had as lieve hear a Grey-hound with Trillo's and long Graces, sing a Love Song to the Moon; But much rather hear my Mastiff teaching my Neighbour's Hog his Gamut, when he comes into my Ground.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p:
What think you of a broken Consort of Violins
and Theorbo's joyn'd 〈◊〉 Italian Voices. I'll have that for you.—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I had rather hear a Broken Consort in my Hogyard: My Bores and Sows grunt out Harmonious Bases, my Hogs sing out their Brisker Countenours, my sweet voic'd Pigs squeak out Melodious Trebles.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What think you of a Consort of Cathedral Voices.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I had rather hear sweet Frogs chant out their Anthems against Rain, joyn'd with the passionate voices of old Toads. And for my more sprightly Musick— Schreech Owls, and a Consort of Cats run mad for Love, with the Harmonious braying of some Asses; joyn'd to these a Paper-Mill for an Organ, a Pewterer, Silver-Smith, Trunk-Maker, with Tinkers playing thorough Bases upon Kettles. Tell not me of Musick; dispatch my Business.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Come I will withdraw with you, and Sign and Seal.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Ladies, I will wait on you again instantly.

div.stage: [Exit all but Bell. Wild. Celia, Chloris.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Survey my youth, and reslect upon your own Beauty, and immagin whether it be possible to forbear thinking or talking of Love when we meet—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Neither thinking nor talking of Love will do the business, I am engaged to Sir Nicholas Peakegoose, and would not be false for the whole world, I swear—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: True to him, 'tis impossible; you cannot love him, he's ugly and foolish—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Oh, but he's very good natur'd, and admires me extreamly— you that call your selves witty men, have some Love indeed; but 'tis like French Courage, hot in the Onset, and as swift in the retreat—

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: True to a keeper, sure you will not be a thing so out of fashion—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Oh Lord, I would not be false to Sir Christopher Smash for all this earthly good: 'Tis a shame Women should be so false to their Intrigues, as some are; I wonder at their Consciences. What do they think will become of their Souls another day?

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: Love heartily, as I do, and 'twill take away that scruple; let me tell you, 〈◊〉 a great Sin, and I wonder you can have the Conscience not to pity me: For you have struck me to the heart—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: You are pleas'd to say so.

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: Will you hear me swear bloodily? by—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Hold! hold! have you no Religion in you? Lord, how I tremble for fear of an Oath!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis true, he pays for your Body; but 'tis not fit he should have your mind: let me but have that—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: That will not serve your turn.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No,— But if I have the Mind once, I am sure the Body is not far off, which would be ne'r the worse for Sir Nicholas should I leave it, which I never would—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Shall it ever be said that I am false to my Keeper?—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, it shall never be told; and if it were, hee'd ne'r believe it, who is so conceited of himself, that he thinks you love him.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: We of our Profession must be as careful of our Credit as Merchants and Bankers should be; if we break with one, we shall ne'r be trusted by another.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Care to conceal is good; but barren Truth is good for nothing: The falsest Women like the greatest Knaves, thrive most.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I should love at another rate than your Friend Swash; I should not leave you for the love of Bottles and the Company of Bullies, to roar, and scowr, and break Windows.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Indeed he is a little too wild, but he has the prettiest merry humours with him—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I desire but to visit you, while Drink makes him unfit for you; I am sure you do not love him.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: No, why he's the prettiest wittiest wild Gentleman about the Town: He says the Wits love him dearly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: All Love is in equality. I am sure you cannot love him whom you keep under like a Spaniel.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Indeed I keep him in Discipline; do not Fathers love their Children, yet keep 'em at a distance.

div.stage: Enter Sir Christopher Swash, Blunderbus, and Heildebrand.

lg.l: LEt's Drink, let's Drink all Day and Night Give each a lusty Bowl:
This is the ravishing Delight Of ev'ry Thirsty Soul;
Let others soak all Night in Beds And live but half their time,
The Wine that's always in our Heads Shall still preserve us in our prime, Shall still, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir Christ.
sp.p: The Devil take me Blunderbus and Heildebrand, if we be nt very mad Fellows.

sp.speaker: Celia▪
sp.p: This is Sir Christopher Swash, and his two Bullies.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Ounds! what Prigg is yon talking with your Natural—

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Shall I pluck out Porker, and lay him on thick?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: No, he's my friend, an honest fellow, and as mad a fellow as the best of us. Honest Wildman Oylie, how dost thou do? How dost Prigg Bellamy? Gad we have had a rare Night on't, we have roar'd, and sung and ranted; kick't all Males, kiss'd all Females, swing'd Constables and Watches, trounced Bailiffs, broke Windows and stormed Bawdy-houses, and committed other outrages to the confusion of much people—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Oh, fie my Dear; why wouldst thou venture thy Person, when thou know'st how I love thee? get thee gon, Thou art such a wild thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Peace, my Buttock, no harm done; we have not been in Bed these four and twenty hours.

lg.l: Let others soak all Night in Beds, &c. [Sings.
And live but half their time, &c.

sp.p: On my Conscience and Soul we broke Fourscore pounds worth of Windows.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Is not this a pretty Gentleman to be in Love with?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Pray, know my Friends, Blunderbus and Heildebrand: They are as honest fellows as e'r drank Beer-glass, and as brave as ever stood Cannon-bullet— But where's Sir Humphrey? hey— hey—

lg.l: The Wine that's always in our Heads
Shall still preserve us in our prime.

sp.p: Am not I a very mad fellow, Ha, Sir Humphrey— Hey boys! let▪ me kiss thee, Oylie—

div.stage: Enter Sir Humphrey, Phillis, and Steward.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Sir Christopher Swash, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Let me present these Gentlemen to you they are of good Families; Their Name Blunderbus and Heildebrand.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: They are great Names indeed; but they are something negligently dress'd—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: That's all one, they are as brave as Lightning; and will kick Bailiffs like Thunder, and faith they'l scowr and roar like Cannon. They are the best Company in the world, and are my Life-guard against Bailiffs.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: They look dreadfully—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Dreadfully! so they do; why each of 'em has kill'd his man. But as they are very brave, so they are very ingenious, and rare Company— Here's Heildebrand has a number of the purest Bawdy Songs, and will Sing and Play a thorow▪ base with his fingers rubbing too and fro upon a Table thus, most incomparably; and then Blunderbus will hoop, hollow, and hunt over a Bottle with any man in Europe, and they are the bravest Catch-singers both of 'em—

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Nay, gad Sir Nicholas, you make me blush.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Upon my honour, you Compliment!

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Because they say so now, you shall hear 'em sing— a Boat, a Boat.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Come on.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: To please you—
A Boat, a Boat, haste to the Ferry, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Are not we mad Fellows? Faith we can be merry and we set on't; we have roar'd and scowr'd, and kept Covent-garden waking all last Night.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: On my Conscience we beat Threescore people.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Ay, Fourscore, Men, Women, and Children— ha, was not that well?

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Oh very well! Hark you Gentlemen, a Design comes into my Head of carrying this roaring Company, the Women and the Fiddles to that wretch Gripe's House—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That will be very well— 'Twill fright him out of his Wits, and perhaps free his Wife into the Bargain—

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Whose Caravan is that other which yon spruce Prigg talks with—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: A Coxcomb's, one Sir Nicholas Peak-goose.—

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Does yon fellow manage her?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: No, she's kept I tell you: Do you think a Woman that's kept would lye with another?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: We shall certainly have very good sport.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: 'Tis resolv'd, Sir Christopher— we have resolv'd that all this Company, and my Fiddles, shall forthwith go to the wretch Gripe's House, and Rant and Sing, Dance and Roar, and play pranks there—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Hey Boys! Hey! a most admirable Design— Wee'l tear the ground, and roar, and make more noise than a Sea-Fight.

lg.l: Good store of brisk Claret supplies, &c.
And the Man that is Drunk is as great as a King.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Well said, Sir Christopher, d'ye hear Steward, bid all my Coaches be brought to the Gate; and provide a Collation fit for us, as you tender your Ears; and send all my Fiddles and Voices to Gripe's with the Collation—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Come! let's march on, Blunderbus and Heildebrand; we will break Windows all the way we go, Kick every Male from a Link-boy to a Lord upwards; Kiss every Female, from the Simpering Lady to the Widemouth Jade that crys Sprats; Swinge Bum-bailiffs excessively, and commit filthy outrage, to the astonishment of the Mobile: Come along.

div.stage: Good store of good Claret supplies, &c.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Where have you been roguing Sirrah, that you did not wait on me home?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I stay'd to do a thing I am not us'd to, fill my Belly, enjoy my Friends, and be Merry.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Oh Devil— I think the Rogue stinks of Strong-Beer, foh—▪

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: That's a lye. 'Tis Wine! Cry you mercy Sir, is that a stink? here's Sir Humphrey's good Health— He's a Noble person, will you pledge me, Sir—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Heav'n and Earth! the Impudent Rogue's Drunk—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I have Drank and Victual'd at Sir Humphrey's for a Months Famine I am to endure here— I am hung round with Bottles and stuft full of Provision; will you eat a Pullet?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Oh impudent Villain! bring Drunkenness into my House—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Ay, or else I ne'r should have found it here—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Audacious Villain! Thou stay'st not in my House— I will turn thee away presently—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: The best News I have heard these ten days—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Say'st thou so Rogue, no, I will have thee whipt soundly▪ And in the mean time I will beat thee damnably, to tame thy damn'd unruly Senses. Thou base, filthy Swine—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Here's Twelve Go-downs more upon Reputation, to Sir Humphrey's Health—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I'll health you Rogue! take that— I'll mawl your Rogueship—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: 'Twas base to take advantage of my Drinking. Stand off, I say; for if you strike once more, take notice good Claret has taken away the relation betwixt us, and I shall grow damnably passionate—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Ha! the Rogue may kill me in his Drink, and for ought I know rob me, which is worse. Go, and bid the Maid set on the Pipkin with the black Pudding for your Mistresse's Supper and mine.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: A Pox on Pipkins— I have brought my Mistress some cram'd Chickens, Westphalia Bacon, Neats Tongues, and something else in my Breeches— I have an honour for my Mistress, and should be loath to see her want.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Thy Back shall be mawl'd for this at Bridewell to Morrow; Rogue, Dog, Son of a Whore: Richard, sell that Wine and Provision, and I will put the Money out for thee. 'Twill come to a pretty Sum in a year—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I scorn Usury: Do you think I'll be curst as you are?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: As I am! Rogue—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Good words, I say,— for I am in an ill humour, and shall be suddenly provoked; but to shew I am in perfect Charity with you, here's to my Mistresse's health, I honour her most immaculately—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Go, go— out, and sleep and be sober—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Well, farewel; I'll not keep such base sober Company—

sp.speaker: Gripe▪
sp.p: To morrow shall thy Carcass suffer, and thy Senses be tamed. Here Mally! where art thou? Come we will walk and take the Air, that thou may'st get a Stomach to thy Supper.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: 'Twere well if I could get a good Supper to my Stomach.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I keep a temperate Diet to preserve us. Do not they that fare hardest live longest?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I can endure your dissembling no longer. 'Tis for the love of vile Money, and not care of my Health. I have born thy Tyranny too long.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I Save▪ to make thee a rich Widow— I think the Woman begins to be peevish. Come, I will kiss thee, and put thee in good humour, feth I will.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Kiss a Death's head! a Coffin! my Mother betray'd me in my Youth to the slavery of thy Age. Thou didst promise to be a Father to me; thou canst not be a Husband, and wilt not be a Father— but a cruel Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Be not perverse; for by Cock and Bottle, Heav'n forgive me for Swearing— I will give thee Conjugal Chastisement—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Sheart! talk no more to me of that, you have worn out all my patience; and I henceforward will be a Tigress to thee.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Audacious!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I have a Brother, who comes this Night to Town, he loves me, we were Twins, he'll right me; Thou never saw'st him, but shortly to thy cost thou shalt— His Serjeant spoke to me out at my Prison Window, he is beating up Drums for a supply for Flanders. There is not a fiercer young Officer in the Army: He'll cut thy Throat if thou abusest me so.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Death, is that Hectorly Fellow come, you use to threaten me with? Oh Impudence! my Family is turn'd Topsy-turvy—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I will have the same Christian Liberty that others of my quality have, I will visit and be visited—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Visits with a Pox; ay, that way come Messages, Tokens, Letters and Bawding for one another, and the Frolick goes round.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I will have Money enough to venture 50 l. in a Night at Ombre.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Ounds 50 l. she makes me tremble!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I'll make you know the right of an English Woman before I have done.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Prodigious and amazing! the right of an English Woman to cheat and cuckold her Husband! in into your Chamber! go in, I say!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Peace, old Fool. I say not in.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Nay then Correction will ensue▪

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Yes! that it shall old Tyrant—
sp.stage: He lifts up his Cane, she wrests it out of his hand.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: What noise is that?

div.stage: Enter a Servant of Sir Humphrey Scattergood.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, My Master is just entring with a great Train of Gentlemen and Ladies, and has sent a Collation and Bottles of Wine, that you may not be at Charges.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Confound him and his Train. D'e hear Mrs. go into your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I will stay to entertain the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Ladies! Whores▪ a Plague on 'em all! in, in, or this knife shall be embrued in thy Blood.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Help! help! I will not go in.

div.stage: Enter Sir Humphrey, Sir Christopher, Bellamy, Wildman, Heildebrand and Blunderbus, with Phillis, Celia, Chloris. Servants, Fiddles, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: What's the matter! at wars with your Wife?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: My dear Wife! No— She is not well, she will endanger her health; which is very dear to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I am well— I shall not endanger my health, nor is it dear to him. Ladies, your humble Servant, I am proud of the honour of this visit.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Ounds! she can Compliment. Death they kiss too most Lasciviously—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: How dost thou do, old Boy! we are come to Drink, Sing, Roar, and be merry with thee,

lg.l: The Kings most faithful Subjects we
In's Service are not Dull,
We drink to show our Loyalty
And make his Coffers full.
Would all his Subjects drink like us,
We'd make him richer far,
More Powerful and more Prosp'rous▪
Then all the Eastern Monarchs are,
Then all, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Madam! I come to endeavour your release, and therefore be ready at the first opportunity.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: You oblige me.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Have you any private business with my Wife?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: What a Pox, do you interrupt a Gentleman, that's talking to your Wife— hah!

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: He deserves Chastisement, you uncivil old Prigg.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: If he had offer'd that to me, I would have blown him into Atoms.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Shall I beat him, and kick him damnably, and break his Windows, Sir Humphrey, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Not yet! Come Ladies, I have brought my Fiddles. Let's have a Dance in the first place.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: What will become of me! Hell is broke loose. Huswife, remember this.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Come Mr. Gripe, will you joyn with us?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: No Sir, I thank you Richard; raise the Constable and a strong Watch against these outragious Rascals.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Sir, I will not for the world; Sir Humphrey is my Friend, and I love and honour him; and here's another Rous to his health.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Hell and Confusion! Damn'd Rogue! I'll murder thee.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: You shall not starve me as long as Sir Humphrey lives, i'gad.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Ounds! She dances, a very damn'd confounded TownJade.
sp.stage: They dance a Country Dance, at the end of which Sir Humphrey leads her out Dancing.
sp.p: Hell and Devils! what trick's this— oh my Wife, my Wife, come in you Baggage.
sp.stage: [He runs out and pulls her in.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Are you mad? 'Tis part of the Dance.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: You shall lead her no such Dance. Here Huswife, get you into your Chamber.—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: What do you interrupt the Dance? Earthquakes, Inundations, roaring Seas and Thunder, I'll mawl ye.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: There's rare taming of your Senses for you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Excellent— I'll not take 200 l. for this beating.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Break all the Windows— Heildebrand and Blunderbus—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Hold, hold! what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Good again, very good.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: At your Command much may be done, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Sirrah! Fill every one a Brimmer to Mrs. Gripe's health. Give Gripe one.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Take it, and drink it to your Ladie's health; or by the Soul of Scanderbeg I will carbonado thy old musty Body.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Plagues! and Curses! well, there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Down on your Knees all. Strike up Fiddles, an Alarm, Fire all— Hey Boys—

lg.l: Good store of brisk Claret supplies ev'ry thing,
And the Man, &c.

sp.p: Am not I a very mad fellow, Sir Humphrey?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Did you ever see such an odious old fellow?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Women, I see can lye by any nauseous Rascals, if they'l marry them or keep 'em— I am sure you cannot nor shall not love Sir Nicholas

sp.speaker: Wildm.
sp.p: Prithee! think no more of that Roister.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Really he's a pretty witty wild Creature.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Gentlemen, what have I done to deserve these Outrages?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Done! Damm'e you are a Rogue, and an Usurer, Sirrah!

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Done! filthy fellow to shut up your Wife against the Law of Nature.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: We come to oblige you, to visit and be merry with you and your Lady—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Hands all around▪ We'll Dance about him, till you run away with his Wife. Play Fiddles— fa, la, la, la, la.

sp.speaker: Sir Hum.
sp.p: Come Madam,— break off—
sp.stage: He breaks off with Mrs. Gripe▪— As he's going off, Gripe creeps under their Legs.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Come back Whoremaster! have I caught you, Strumpet? remember there is Law Sir. Remember that—

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: What does the Scoundrel talk of Law?

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Beat his Brains out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Now Gentlemen, you must give me leave to say you do not well to triumph o're an old Man. He is my Husband, and I must love him; though he uses me tyrannically, and shuts me up in Prison—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: How, shut up your Wife!

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: How, shut up your Wife!

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: How, shut up your Wife!

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Oh thou old Dotard. Thou shame of Mankind!

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Woman was meant to go at large: Thou filthy Creature.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Shall Woman, that's wild by Nature, be tam'd by thee base Fellow?

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: He invades the right of Whoremasters, and 'tis not to be born; we have the right of Commonage, and he impales.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Heav'n protect me but this once, I seldom trouble it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I am resolv'd to escape, but not in such lewd Company. Richard, Do you stand here whatever happens till I come to you, and do as I direct you, and I'll reward you—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Any thing; for I love and honour you, and scorn and hate my Master.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Yet I say, Mally, good Mally go into my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I perceive their intentions are base— I will my dear, instantly▪ Sir, put out all the Candles, and I'll secure my Escape.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: With all my heart, Gentlemen, assist me in this Design.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
The Candles are out— murder, murder, help, help. I am cuckolded, rob'd, undone. Murder! Villains, Thieves, Murderers,
Whoremasters, Sons o' Whores, Rascals, Strumpets—
sp.stage: [Mrs. Gripe puts a loose Gown on Richard.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Where art thou, my Dear? I will go in with thee, I am convinc'd I was in the wrong.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Come my Dear, give me thy hand, my good Dear; I'll mawl thee with a Plague to thee for this— anon—
sp.stage: [Aside. [Gripe leads Rich. into the Chamber for his Wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs Gripe.
sp.p: Now— farewel old Tyrant, and all the rest of ye; if I had escap'd by violence, I had had a hue and cry after me, and been stopt presently—

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Gad! its dark— have at these Women— Ounds you Son of a Whore.
sp.stage: Kisses Cel. Bell. strikes him, he strikes Blunder.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Lightning and Thunder! what Rascal cufft me? have at somebody.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: What's the Matter! Flamboyes come in.
sp.stage: They draw, Women shriek and get out.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: I'll stand up against the Wall. Fight on my merry men all—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Oh for some Murder among themselves.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: What's the matter here?

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: I was boxt!

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: I was cufft!

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Come brave Boys: 'twas in the dark, and 'tis no dishonour, ne'r mind it.

lg.l: He that wears a brave Soul, and dares handsomly do,
Is a Herauld to himself, and a Godfather too.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Some other time let this be examin'd—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Now you'l be gon; She you came for is safe! all your force cannot break open that Dore. There lies your way—

sp.speaker: Footm.
sp.p: He is mistaken, the Lady took one of the Coaches by your order, she said, and is gon—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Let's be gon and look after the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: I shall make some smoak.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Blood shall ensue—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I will arrest every man, and when I have recovered Damages, indict 'em for a Riot, poor Fools! This was a lucky adventure, since I have sav'd my Wife. They have left their Banquet and Wine, I will make Money of it. Let me go fasten my Doors.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT. III.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: SO! I have laid up their Provisions, and shall make Money of 'em, as I intend to do of my beating I have had, and the Riot they have committed; I have taken order my drunken Rogue shall be apprehended. But now to my Wife! persidious Jade! I shall keep her Prisoner during life, for all her Hectorly Brother—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: within. I think this disguise will fright him, and secure me from a good substantial beating into the bargain: If I can get once out of the Chamber— I am sure I will face him down I ne'r was in it—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Here! where is this vile 〈◊〉 of Woman-kind? Dost thou hide thy self— hah! Mercy upon me! who's here, the Devil! the Devil!—
sp.stage: [He runs roaring out, the Candle falls.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I thought my Face was pretty well before; but I see I could make it uglier; Art may improve Nature much. Now will I shift for my self—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Help, help! the Devil! the Devil!

div.stage: Richard Re-enters in his own Habit.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: What's the matter Sir?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Oh! the Devil! the Devil in my Chamber!

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Where! where! Let's see. I have lighted the Candle again!

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Oh Rogue! art thou here! I think thou art the Devil, how couldst thou get in else? I lock'd all my dores and search'd every Room in the house, and thou wer't not in any of 'em—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Sir, I was grown a little soberer with the fright of the Swords drawn, and sensible of my fault, I hid my self from your Indignation under my Flock-bed, where I have lain and sweat and trembled, till I heard you cry out, and I could not but come to your assistance:

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
That makes some amends. Let's into my Wife's Chamber and see what's the matter, may be 'twas a trick of the lewd Woman's
to fright me, I am sure I put her in there— I led her by the hand my self—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Be not afraid, Sir, sure 'twas no Devil you saw! have you not some guilt upon your Conscience?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Sawcy Rogue, I guilt— I have none— I am as innocent as the Child new born. Come— let's in Rasoal. Oh Heav'n! what noise is that, Richard? I say, Richard, keep close to me Sirrah, close—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Here's no body in the Chamber—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: What do you say, no body? Look about the Bed, and in and under it quickly—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Here is no body: Did you lead any body in here?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I did— I had her by the hand I thought. And she spoke to me as she went in.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Without doubt it was the Devil, and he is vanish'd—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Hell and Confusion!

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Now I think on't, when I ran out at the quarrel, I thought I saw my Mrs. go out hastily, take one of Sir Humprey's Coaches, and hurry away with it.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Oh horror! oh infamous Strumpet! I am rob'd, cuckold'd, abus'd; oh vilainous quean, she is now in the filthy act of cuckolding me. Hell and Devils! give me my broad Sword.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Good Sir, call upon no Devils; we shall be torn in pieces.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I care not what becomes of me; give me my broad Sword, I'l fetch a Warrant to search that Rogue Scattergood's house, apprehend the Strumpet, bring her home, and murder her; seize upon his Estate, sue him to Outlaries innumerable, indict him and all the Rogues for Riots, &c. give me my broad Sword. Come along with me:

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I dare not.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I'll cut you off in the middle if you do not; get you before, I'll lock the doors: Oh whore, whore, whore!

div.stage: Enter Sir Chr. Swash, Heildebrand, and Blunderbus.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Hey Boys, bravely done! scowr on! break those Windows, 'tis Normandy Glass, scowr, scowr.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Have at 'em.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Fall on, fall on.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: 'Tis enough, march on; My Blunderbus and Heildebrand, we will over-run the Town, as easily as Alexander did Asia.
sp.stage: [A Citizen and his Wife walk by.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: A Prize! a Prize!

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Lay her aboard.

sp.speaker: Citiz.
sp.p: She's my Wife, Gentlemen, what would you have?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: All kiss her— fall to, Boys.

sp.speaker: Citiz.
sp.p: Help, help! Watch, Watch!

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Murder, murder! help, help.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Ounds you Rogue d'ye call the Watch! Swinge him. There's for you Sirrah!

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Does she cry out? lay her on.
sp.stage: Citizen and Wife run out calling out help. Heild. strikes her.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: 'Gad we are very mad fellows, Are not we? my Bullies.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Damme as e'r wore Swords. I take it.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: More game, more game; have at 'em perverse Whores, a Pox on 'em, they are past squeaking in private, though they do it in publick.

div.stage: Enter two or three Old Women.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Who are these? Curse on 'em, they are old and ugly—

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Herb-women, going to Market.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Let 'em be what they will, I spare no Sex nor Age. Beldams, you must be kiss'd for being women, and kick'd for being ugly. The Devil take me if the Town can match us for tearing Blades now.

div.stage: Enter two or three Apprentices singing and breaking Windows.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Stand! who are these? Rascals without Swords, Apprentices? must such Rogues as you usurp the priviledge of Gentlemen? such Scoundrels as you scowr? lay 'em on thick. let's swinge 'em—

sp.speaker: Apprentices.
sp.p: Help, help! Watch, Watch! Murder.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Death! Shall such pitiful fellows think to do like us?

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Who's here? stand.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Stand Rogues: ha! they'r Fidlers.

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.p: We are going to Play under a window for a Wedding.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: We'll stop your Journey, Rascal; strike up, and play to us while we break windows.

sp.speaker: Fidl.
sp.p: Good Gentlemen! we shall lose our Wedding; there are other Companies out that will be there before us.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: We will cut and hack you first, and then your Fiddles.

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.p: Hold, hold Gentlemen! we will Play—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Now let's break Windows to this Musick. 'Tis good for nothing else. Pull down all the Knockers, and wipe out the Milk scores: will this Rogue my Footman never come with Lamb-black, and a Brush that we may blot out the signs.

div.stage: Enter Citizen, with the Constable and Watch.

sp.speaker: Citiz.
sp.p: These are the Rogues that set upon me and my Wife.

sp.speaker: Consta.
sp.p: Rogues! Sir Christopher Swash, and his Friends; They use to give us Money every night Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Watchmen.
sp.p: Ay, ay, very honest Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Consta.
sp.p: You are a sawcy fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Constable, let me kiss you; There's half a piece for your Watch to drink.

sp.speaker: Consta.
sp.p: Thanks, noble Sir Christopher. Who are you Sir? I must have an account of you.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: Ay, what are you?

sp.speaker: Citiz.
sp.p: I am an honest Man, and pay Scot and Lot in my Parish, and these Fellows set upon my Wife and me.

sp.speaker: Consta.
sp.p: Stay Fidlers▪ whither are you sneaking?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: This fellow is a Rogue, and pickt up a Whore, and call'd her his Wife.

sp.speaker: Consta.
sp.p: Away with him to the Gatehouse—

sp.speaker: Citiz.
sp.p: Very fine.—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Now honest Constable we are well met. And I have Fiddles, ' G●…d you shall Dance to 'em.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Any thing Master that you please.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: When that's done, go into your Huts, drink Brandy like Dutch Skippers, and smoak like double Chimneys for the good and security of the Nation! while we scowr afresh.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Come fellows, strike up—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Very well— I vow.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Good morrow to your Worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Good morrow!

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: We are undon, yonder's the High Constable going the Rounds to Night! haste every one to his Post—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Who's here, Sir Nicholas Peakgoose! i'faith thou shalt roar and sing, and break Windows—

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Not for the world, Gentlemen; I am going to fetch my Celia from Sir Humphrey's house, if she find me in drink, she'll be outragious.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Gad you shall: hang sneaking after a Whore; Keep her under.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Pray Sir excuse me.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Gad do as I bid you, or fight.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Fight! oh Lord, fight! what would she say to me, if I should venture my self to fight?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Prithee don't stand prating, but roar and break Windows, or draw.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: I am resolv'd, I'll not draw: What will you have me do? what will become of me?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Follow us—

lg.l: Diseases and Troubles are ne'r to be found,
But in the damn'd place where the Glass goes not round.

sp.p: Sing with a Pox to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Well, well— Diseases and Troubles, &c.

sp.speaker: H. Const.
sp.p: These are the Bullies that made the Havock last Night in Covent-Garden, and this Night hereabouts; fall on, knock 'em down.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: How now! we must to Battle—

div.stage: Constable and Watch fall on, Sir Nicholas running away is knock'd down and taken, the rest with broken Heads escape, and get to Sir Humphrey's House.

sp.speaker: H. Const.
sp.p: Come Sirrah! have we taken ye? we see where the others are gotten in.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Gentlemen, as I hope to be sav'd I was none of their Company; but they set upon me, and threatned to kill me if I went from 'em. I will be a witness against them.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: 'Tis Sir Nicholas Peakgoose; a very civil Gentleman.

sp.speaker: H. Const.
sp.p: I know him! you will be forth coming in the Morning to witness against 'em—

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: H. Const.
sp.p: Go! good night. Beset Sir Humphrey Scattergood's house, we'll have 'em and they be alive.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Good night Gentlemen: Oh my Head and Shoulders! a deuce take their scowring, for me—

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Heav'n how he melts his Time and Land away in Luxury and Sloath, and I by force must be an Instrument in his wickedness; now must I keep the Dore, while he, his Friends and Whores are lolling in their Baths, prepar'd with cost befitting Emperors; nay, They're perhaps revelling in the height of Sin— but I will pray and read these godly Meditations by my self—

div.stage: Enter Sir Christopher, Blunderbus, and Heildebrand.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Hear you old formal Steward, where is your Master?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Bless me, what ails you all? are your Brains beaten out?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: No, we have had a Battle with the Myrmidons of St. Martins, we have swinged, and are swinged—

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: I am sure my Porker is embrued in Blood.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: And mine is stain'd in gore of filthy Peasant.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Bless us! Heav'n! Have you committed Murder?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Prithee leave prating, and open the door; we heard the Musick this way, thy Master's there.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: You must not pass; my Master and his Friends are all in Baths.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: And where are the Women, the Cockatrices?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: The Cockatrices are bathing too.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: What mine?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Yes, yours.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: What a Pox, does he manage the Body of your Caravan?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Peace Oylie— his own Convenient's there, we will all run roaring in.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: You cannot pass; there is a Blunderbuss within charged with 15 Bullets, in the hands of a damn'd desperate Rogue.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Pox on't— I know my Buttock's honest; but I care not, for the Devil take me, I drink too much to be a man at Arms. Gad! I only keep her for the lewdness of the matter.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Halloo— Here's Peakgoose. Now you shall drink—

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: 'Gad— we have catch'd you; you shall drink like a Devil.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Ay 'gad shall you— and roar and have t'other Battel too, Boy—

lg.l: The Stars which you see,
In the Hemisphear be
But the studs in your faces with Drinking, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Good Gentlemen, Pardon me. I must go to my Dear. Where is Madam Chloris, Friend?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: You cannot come at her: the Ladies are in one Bathing Room, and the Gentlemen in another just by 'em.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Sir Humphrey will swinge your Buttock away—

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Yes, He or some of'em will manage your Natural gallantly.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Who! my Birds n'eyes. I am sure she would not do such a thing, as I may say, for the world.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Pish! Pox of Whores. Let's go drink 'em out of our heads. Where's the Yeoman of the Cellar?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Why he, or his Servant is never out on't! 'Twill come to a fine pass.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Come along to the Cellar.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Excuse me, I will not go— what to make a Beast of my self?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: If you will not go, Draw! for 'foregod you shall fight.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: What will become of me? with these roaring Fellows I must go.

lg.l: The Sun's gone to Tipple all Night in the Sea Boys,
To morrow hee'l rise, and be paler than we Boys;
Give us Wine, give him Water, 'tis Sack makes us The Boys.

div.stage: Enter Sir Humphrey, Bellamy, and Wildman, in morning Gowns.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: With what variety of pleasure you melt away your hours.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: There's need of Fancy and Invention for such Luxury.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p:
It is beyond the sence of Fops; a Fool has not wit enough to be pleas'd, he but seems merry, when he's sad at heart. Is not this better than venturing life for Ambition, being perpetually anxious for a Blew-Ribbon, or a white-Staff, to have a crowd of Clients sneaking two hours in my Anti▪ Chamber, who crouch like Slaves
when I appear; yet hate and scorn me for my Pride the while?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: These are the irregular appetites of Men, whose Minds are Sick. The vigorous Body and the healthful mind can find no pleasure but in Sense.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Fools are led away by shadows, and let the substance go; while the rash, giddy, and magnanimous Fool runs abroad, is delicately lousie, and kills men for Honour, who never anger'd him: We stay at home and get 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Which I take it, is the more honourable employment of the Two. Another Fop breaks his Brains with Metaphysical Nonsence, a Mathematical Coxcomb besots himself with a, b, c, Superficies, Lines and Angles; our Virtuoso contemplates Lice in Microscopes; your Orator studies to show his parts in Whipt-Creamspeeches; your Schoolman wasts his time in Bulls and Nonsensical Distinctions to make the same thing differ from it self; and your politick. Owl drudges and makes a business of what is none—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And all the while the Senses are neglected.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Your drudging Millhorse Block-head, is useful for Government, while we most wisely find out Pleasures for every Sense; we are Lords o'th' world, and enjoy all in it, while they are Slaves—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Twas not our fault, we did not please every Sense even now. These pretty Whores are skittish.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: We could do nothing with 'em but put them to the squeak a little.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Some of these kept-Ladies, will no more treat you with Love, than Taverns will with Wine; 'tis against their Trade: But I have had 'em all for Money. I cannot, like the grand Signior, make a Wench come when I give my Handkerchief: But if I see a pretty Whore I like, I send her 50 l. and to that Lure she stoops, and strait I Truss her: if not, a 100 l. brings her down: my Money is less precious than my Time.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Faith, you are in the right: I see what 'twill come to— for I have a damnable mind to that pretty Jade Celia.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And I must have my Chloris, whatever becomes of me.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Sir Humphrey! Your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Sir Nicholas Peakgoose! your Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Where is my Mistress, poor Rogue?

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Within, with her Companions.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: I long to see her, pretty Rogue. I have not seen her these six hours, and yonder's Sir Christopher Swash— and his Hectorly Companions will kill me with drinking Bumpers, as they call 'em, if you protect me not; they draw and threaten to fight with me, if I do not drink; I have been knock'd down by the Watch, for being taken for one of his lewd Company already. Hide me— hide me.

div.stage: Enter Sir Christopher, Blunderbus, and Heildebrand.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Where is this Scoundrel, that basely flies from a Bumper? Draw! I will have satisfaction. I will Tap him, and let out the Claret he has drank already.
