sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Good Sir Christopher, spare his life for my sake.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: For your sake he lives; but upon condition, he shall come down and drink lustily—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: What makes you bloody?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: We have had a Skirmish, faith. Would you had been with us, I never saw better scowring days of my life; but now we are here, let's all down and drink bloodily.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: There's no life to drinking, roaring, and lying rough.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: There's no pleasure in a single Drunkenness. But Sir Nicholas and we lead a life, we!

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Let us borrow Sir Nicholas a quarter of an hour, till he sees his Mistress, and then we'll restore him—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: D'ye hear Nick? Be sure you come, or by Heav'n I'll run you through the Lungs next time I meet you—

lg.l: March on bravely! forward let us go,
Tara ra rant tan tant, tan tan tan ta ra ra
rant tan tan! The Trumpets they do blow.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Oh Lord have have mercy upon me! what shall I do? I'll swear the Peace against him, if I live and breath.
Oh my Dear! Art thou there?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Yes, you Fop; But what do you do here?

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Prithee be not angry Miss. I come to wait on Thee home—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: I'll not go— Go home by your self! go I say, go quickly—

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Good, dear Madam, let me stay.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: I shall have people think you are jealous of me! How dare you come after me thus?

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: I jealous! I'd have 'em to know I scorn their words.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Go home then! get you gone! Why do you stay, when I bid you go? Must you come sneaking after me? Do you think you are fit to be seen in good Company, because I am so?

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: I know I am not; but good, sweet Madam, let me stay here: I beg it on my knees.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Nay, nay, now you are too Cruel: let me intercede for him.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Ay!

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Madam! Pray let me beg for him.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Look you there.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: He shall not stay. Ladies, you don't know what you do, If I shou'd suffer him, he'ld always be peaking after me— Go, I say, I will be obey'd—

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: I'll give thee all the Money I have about me, if thou'lt go home with me.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Come, give it me.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: There.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Well, I will go home, but go you out and wait an hour, till I come.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Well, my Dear, what you will. Good, Sir Humphrey, let your Servants guard me from these Roarers.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Well, poor Rogue, I'll stay. Go! thou art a pretty one.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Sir, the fat Gentlewoman is come with three young Girls.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: There's a Collation waits you; will you come in to it, my Dearest?

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Go! we will follow you—

Now Gentlemen, a consultation: Here are Maiden-heads coming, we'll divide 'em equally. Steward, send her in, and convey her Attendants the back way into my Apartment. And let 'em be bath'd, new rigg'd with Linnen.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: It goes against my Conscience, and is below my Dignity.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Sirrah! Begon! obey me, or you have no Tips of Ears to Morrow—

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Well, I have taken such pains for you, I am ready to expire— I had gotten my house full of handsom Wenches for your Worships use: But I thought the Maiden-heads I spoke of would be more fit, and I have brought 'em all three with much ado.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: And will you warrant 'em Maids?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: That I will upon my sincerity; did I ever deceive you? I have more Conscience than to be corrupt in my Calling, not for this Earth I would not— But these are dearer than I thought. They are 50 l. a piece, if you have 'em: I never higgle or make words with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Talk not of Price! it is my Birth-Night. Gentlemen, I'll treat you like a man of Honour. We'll cast Lots for 'em.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You are too obliging.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: I hae conducted the Gentlewomen— Whores in.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Prethee honest Bawd, go and bring all the Whores in at my back-gate. Do you hear, old Fool? see you entertain 'em well: and let every Stranger and Servant in my House have his Cher entirè. I'll not have a Man-servant idle, nor a Maid-servant honest: Chastity shall be Felony, and Sobriety High-Treason.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Well Sir, I'll fetch 'em all.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Good Sir, will you whip me, hang me, or—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Peace, thou hypocritical old Sot; do you hear, be you Drunk soundly, and Whore lustily, or Wars will ensue between us—

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Whore! oh Lord! I whore? What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Come on my Friends, Let's in and survey my Markettings—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Lead on, my noble Prince of Pleasure; and we'll follow—

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: To the Devil all! and thither I shall follow, unless I suddenly get loose from these clutches.

div.stage: Enter Sir Nicholas Peakgoose, Sir Christopher, Blunderbus, and Heildebrand.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Are you so nimble i'faith! we have catch't you agen!

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: You have made me drunk with these Bumpers. What will you murder me? have some pity on me, on my Knees I beg you'l let me drink no more; what will my Mrs. say?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: You are in a good posture. Kneel all! Fill us t'other Bumper. ' Death! Drink it, I say. Drink it, or Blood will ensue—

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: What will become of poor Sir Nicholas?—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: All together clash.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Well, I must do't.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: T'other round.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Mercy upon me! I am dead! I am kill'd! I'll lay my death to your charge— no more to be said.
sp.stage: [He lets fall the glass, and breaks it.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Ah Rascal, Do you spill your Drink! 'Ownds! fling the rest of the Bumpers in's face.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Murder! Help,— help. I am slain.
sp.stage: They fling all the glasses in's face.

sp.speaker: Without.
sp.p: Open the Dore! we'll break it open—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: What's the matter? Now draw the Fool away; he's dead drunk.

div.stage: Enter Sir Humph. Bell. and Wildman.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: How now! What's the matter without?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir! The High Constable with a huge Guard, and Mr. Gripe in the head of 'em is come with a Warrant to search the house.—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Call up my Servants! fetch my Guns.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Hey Boys! we shall have more scowring!

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Now we shall show our vàlour.

div.stage: Enter Servants with Guns and Pistols.
H. Constable and Watch break in. Gripe and Richard.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: What means this violence?

sp.speaker: H. Const.
sp.p: We have a Warrant to search for Mrs. Gripe.—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Fall on! fall on. We are victorious, and have taken Prisoners.

div.stage: They fall on, beat the Constable and Watch out, return with Gripe, and Richard Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: What will become of us! we shall be Murder'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Lock 'em up, Safe! and guard my house with Guns and Musquets! unseasonable Rascals to interrupt our pleasure.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Shall we plunder, strip, and take the spoil of the Field?

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: No▪ we'll call 'em to a Council of War, and condemn 'em; away with 'em.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: O mercy, mercy!

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: What is Sir Nicholas kill'd in the fray?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: No— in our fray; Dead drunk. This was a brave Battle!

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Now all to bed: Carry Sir Nicholas to bed.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Not we! we'll go drink and lie rough! fare you well upon those terms. Come Bullies, I think we have behav'd our selves like Emperours!

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Gripe like a young Officer, and her Brother's Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Am I compleatly set out like a young Officer? Do my Brother's Accoutrements sit well upon me?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: They become you admirably; you are as brisk, as fierce an Officer as the best of 'em; and so like your Brother, 'tis amazing, had not I been privy to your Design and his, I should have sworn you were my Captain.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: That likeness between us will further my design. My Husband knows nothing of my Brother, but that he has heard we are so like, that upon an Experiment I drest my self in man's clothes once, and we were not known from one another. But do I strut, cock, and look fierce enough?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: To a Miracle! But since you have this design upon your Husband to fright and make him yield to good terms, why would you not let your Brother carry it on?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: He resents so much the base usage of me, that I know not what his passion might have provok'd him to: Besides, it seems to be the right of an English Woman to Hector her own Husband; and faith, I'll have him under my Command now, or press him for Flanders.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Bravely resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I'll teach Húsbands to provoke their own Flesh.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: That is out of his power or yours to do to him—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I'll make him such an example. I'll make all Husbands have a care, how by Injuries they sower their Wive's love into revenge, or their meekness into rage. I know he's a Coward, as all Tyrants are; and I'll make him e're I have done, as dearly as he loves his Money, part with a good Sum for fear of his life—

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Methinks they that live so miserably, shou'd not fear to dye—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Oh yes! They are such Fools to choose the worst part of life, and are yet greater Fools, and prefer it to Death, which is far better: to be dead, is to be insensible; but to have senses and deny 'em all, is worse. Do you find him out, and get him to a private place, and let me alone.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: I will, Madam! 'Sheart I shall forget to call you Captain.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Well, I shall strut, look big, and huff enough for a Captain, I warrant you▪ by your leave Modesty for a while. A desperate ill, must have a desperate cure: But these words of Command stick in my Throat, and I cannot swear worth a farthing.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Oh use, use! 'tis nothing but use—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: But why must we use French Discipline? we did not so when Henry the Fifth beat 'em.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Why, by plaguing the world this Ten years, they have found a better way than we have.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Well, I'll try! Let me con— Even your Ranks. Straiten your Files. Shoulder all. Rest your Arms. To the right, to the right, to the right. To the left, to the left, to the left. Dam'me what awkard Rogue is this?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: O brave Captain! well done! But 'twas a little o'th hardest.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I'll warrant you— I'll lay it on— let me alone for Discipline— allòns.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT. IV.
div.stage: Enter Sir Nicholas Peakgoose Drunk at play, with Blunderbus and Heildebrand.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: PRay Gentlemen, let me give over play. You have gotten my Gold Watch, and Diamond Ring, and 20 l. upon Tick.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Nay, 'gad you shall play t'other 20 l.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Lord! what would you have of a man? I cann't abide play: I hate it mortally, so I do.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: What a Pox! you don't take us for Cheats, do you?

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Who I? Not I Gentlemen, for the world! yet I doubt they are little better!

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Dam'me! 'Tis not your best course.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: You shall find us Gentlemen: That scorn to do or suffer an ill Thing. Therefore play on.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Heav'n deliver me from these dreadful Bullies: They will get all my Money, or quarrel with me.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: What a Devil do you mean? will you play, or no?

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen don't be angry, I will then double, or quit. I'll set you the 20 l. because I will make an end, Mr. Heildebrand; but I vow and swear, I'll play no more after that.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Are you sure the Doctors are in, Blunderbus?

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Yes, I am sure! at it Man!

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Come then! here'sat it, 7.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: 12! 'tis out! quit.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: I Nickt you! ask Blunderbus.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Nay, then I'll never play more▪ 12▪ Nick 7. Do what you will with me, I'll not throw a Die more. What a Pox▪ Do you think I am a Fool?

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: If you do this Heildebrand, you will lose him for ever; a Plague of ill luck—

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Was it 12?

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Ay marry was it! ask Mr. Blunderbus else.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Yes it was: Sir Nicholas is in the right, look you there now.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Look you there now.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: No more to be said.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Well, Good morrow, Gentlemen, your humble Servant. Now we are quit I'll play no more really.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Nay, you shall not go▪ the Devil take me if you don't play one 20 l. more.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Never speak on't, you shall play for one 20 l. more, if you were my Father. Zounds! you don't take us for Snaps, do you?

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: I will not play, I will not! I will not! what will you do with me? Help, help.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Run Blunderbus, we shall lose our Bubble.
sp.stage: [Sir Nich. runs out they after him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I see already that this is a fine civil well-govern'd Family. You must guard me.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: I warrant you, Captain. Where are the Servants? they have been all drunk, and roaring all night, and I believe are all asleep.
Oh! here's one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I must needs speak with Sir He Scattergood. Pray let him know I wait for him. My Business is earnest.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: I shall Sir—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: You are sure my Husband is here?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Yes, one of the Watch told me, That when they were beaten Sir Humphrey took him Prisoner.
This is Sir Humphrey.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe▪
sp.p: Sir, your most humble Servant. I hope you will excuse this Disturbance, when you shall know my Busmess.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: A Gentleman's Commands can never disturb me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Sir, I am Brother to the unfortunate Mrs. Gripe, the Wife of a wretched Usurer; who, I am inform'd is in your House.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: He is Sir, but I should have taken you for her, Her self in man's habit.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: A Woman! He has been my Captain abroad these four years; if you had seen what brave Actions he has perform'd in the midst of fire and smoak, you would not have taken him for a Woman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I should not wonder much at your mistake; for just before I went out of England, she was dress▪ d in man's habit; and we were so like, we could not be known asunder.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Indeed I have heard there was a strange likeness betwixt you; the very Look and Voice! hah!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: But Sir, if I be inform'd right, you cannot mistake; for she is in your House.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: She is not, upon my Honour. This is most amazing. I never saw such likeness— They speak so like too—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: If he be here, I beg you will deliver him over to me to used as he deserves; for the Barbarity he has practis'd on my Sister.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: With all my heart Sir! use him at your discretion. My house is free for you, and do you hear, Steward, Bid all my Servants be at the Captain's Command— I should almost have sworn it had been she.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I give you many thanks for this favour, and should be glad to serve you with my Sword.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: You honour me, Sir▪ Fetch down Gripe and his Man: Sir, I will go in and dress me, and then wait on you; and I beg you will make use of my house, and accept of what ever it affords for your Entertainment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: You are very generous and obliging. So, thus far I have acted a 〈◊〉 well 〈◊〉▪

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Oh, here are the Rascals, Captain.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Which is Gripe?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: That old Fellow!

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Look Richard, was ever any one so like my 〈◊〉 Wife? Oh Lord, it is her Brother sure, by the description I have heard.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Is your name Gripe?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Her very Voice too, Richard.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Speak, you Rascal, are you that damn'd fellow Gripe, that Married my Sister— my name is Bevil.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I did Marry one Bevil, and if I did not see you in this Accoutrement, I should take you for her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Her! had you done me one such Injury as she has suffer▪ d Thousands from you, I would have cut your Throat long since: But you know, old villainous Murderer, I am not she: I have been at her house, she's missing, and I doubt not but you have kill'd her; for she is no where to be found, and I am resolv'd to have your Blood for't.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Ha! hum— It must be he! I murder her! Heav▪ n forbid! she is run away from me, and I believe she is in the house playing the Whore here with Sir Humphrey.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Villain! Thou ly'st—
I know her vertue; all thy damn'd Generation put together, have not half her Honesty.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: What will become of me! I tremble all over.▪ Tis he, I heard his Drums beat up yesterday.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I see your Conscience strikes you! had she not been murder'd, she would have come to some of her Relations. Prepare, old Viper▪ and pray; for thou hast not a quarter of an hour to live▪ upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Good Sir— Let me go! if she be kill'd, Heav'n knows I had no hand in her Murder.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Sirrah▪ stay, or I'll knock your Brains out.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I see it is her Brother; she had a great respect for me, and would not have used me so.▪ Tis he by his hard blows.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Kneel and Pray, or by Heav'n I'll kill you before you prepare—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I cannot Pray, I cannot prepare— what have I done?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I have lost a Sister▪ and if she be not murder'd, she has been so abusd by you, that nothing but your life shall satisfie, and I shall do my Countrey good Service in ridding it of such a Monster.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Take your course— if he were dead, I should eat again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I'll stay no longer— have at you—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Hold, hold! sweet Sir! good Brother Captain! do but adjourn the Execution till I go home and settle my affairs, and I'll wait on you again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: No Villain, thou shalt die now, at ye—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: O Heav'n▪ I cannot endure it. I cannot pray, do not murder my Soul. I confess I have been a great Sinner: I have wrong'd many young Orphans, and Comfortless Widows—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: And starved your Servants—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Besides, upon the words of a dying man, your Sister run away from me. I lockt her up indeed to save the Honour of your Family; for she is a most salacious Woman—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: He angers me to the quick with that— Thou ly'st old Dotard, Thou dy'st for that—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Oh hold! hold! Let me but live to repent awhile; I do confess I have wrong'd her—

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Hold Sir! Spare his life—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Thank you, good Sir—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Dissuade me not!

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Hold! hold! here's my Man can tell you she ran away from me.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Indeed Captain she did go away, as she had reason; and I help'd her to escape.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Are you such a Rascal to lye for him? No, he dies.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Hear me, good Captain, your Recruits are not yet full: He seems to be a lusty old Fellow, and can carry Arms yet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Say you so?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: What a Devil does he say, Arms? that's as bad!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: If you think so— take him to your Custody. When he is in Flanders, if I hear not of my Sister in a reasonable time I'll kill him. In the mean while I'll put him into the Van on all occasions—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Sir, Sir! why Captain, Noble Captain, I am a most hideous Coward, I shall run away, and spoil all your Men.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: If you do, I will hang you. No resisting, here take a Shilling.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I must confess I have a great respect for a Shilling, and never could refuse one in my life▪

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Enroll his name, and put his Coat on.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Now I hope you'l let me go upon Parol to furnish my self with Necessaries—

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: No: We'll furnish you with them—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Now Sirrah, you are listed; if you run from your Colours, I can hang you by Law—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Heav'n! what am I condemned to?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Here put on your Coat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Kill him if he resist—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: There is Law, and I have Friends—

sp.speaker: Mrs Gripe.
sp.p: You lye Sirrah, you have no Friends; and for Law, I'll make you know that Inter arma silent Leges. Put his Man a Coat on, and List him. There's a Shilling—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: What shall I do— I am a vile Coward! I am as much afraid of Guns, as Indians or Wild-Beasts are—

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Come sirrah, put it on— What's your Name?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: My Name is Richard Grubb—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Carry them into the Court, and teach 'em the use of their Arms: But d'ye hear Serjeant, be not 〈◊〉 of my whistle—

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Come! Honest Comrade Gripe, give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Pox on your Comradeship; I desire no such base Company: Did ever I think to be Comrade to such a fellow?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Now must I learn to lye rough, filch Linnen, steal Poultry, lye with a Sutler's Wife, and be Lousie. Now Master give me your hand, we are Comrades too—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Rogue! I shall live to remember you. What shall I do? All my Writings will be embezz'led, I shall be utterly ruin'd, my Mortgages lost, my Money conceal'd—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Fear not, Sir, you'll live better with 8 d. a day, than ever you did. I make no doubt but you will save Money at the years end to put out to use— For my part, I am glad that I shall wear Cloaths, and eat.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Now 〈◊〉, your Captain is gone in; honest Comrade, 'tis in your power to oblige your self and me very much: I▪ ll▪ give you Ten Shillings, and your own agen, if you will let me escape.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: How the Rogue values his Liberty.
No, good Sir, get you out. I'll borrow two of Sir Humphrey's Musquets, and Exercise you—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I'll give, a 11.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: No,— go out, I say.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Good Comrade— I'll give you 12.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Get you out—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Hold— 13.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: No— I'll not be cashier'd for you—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Cashier me; I'll give 14.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: No— I tell you—

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Out I say—

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Out, or I▪ ll send you out.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Go.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: I'll knock you down.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: 20. Have you no mercy in you?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: The Rogue bids for his Liberty, as if it were a stock at 12 d. Gleek.

div.stage: Enter Sir Humphrey, Mrs. Gripe, Bellamy, and Wildman.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Was there ever such likeness between two, as betwixt this Captain and his Sister▪

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: It is Prodigious— I never heard her speak but once, and methinks their Voices have some likeness.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: They have so— This is a very Effeminate man to look at, yet they report him to be a brave Fellow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: You oblige me beyond return.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: I have often heard of your worth, and think my self happy in this opportunity of knowing you— My house is a house of freedom, Command it. If you have a mind to a fresh hansom Wench, as that's no great question to a young Officer, you shall have her—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: To us that have been in the Camp, That's no ill Proposal; and faith Gentlemen, you shall find me a Man at Arms in all points—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: In the mean time here is my Mistress, I bar her— But the other two, if you can win 'em, do—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: And faith I ll try 'em. I am resolved to carry on this frolick as far as 'twill go.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: This is the Captain that's so like his Sister

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: There is a strange resemblance betwixt 'em—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: I never saw one so like another days o' my breath.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: He is a mighty pretty Man.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: A fine Gentleman as e're I saw—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: He is a very sweet Person indeed.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha! I'like not these proceedings. This Beardless Officer will be too hard for us.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh these Wenches love a fellow with a Scarf, or an Ar●…e Belt mightily.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: My Dear, I have a Lawyer and Writings ready for that Settlement thou wert pleas'd to promise me, if thou wilt dispatch it now, not that I desire it; but in case of Mortality: for while thou livest I desire nothing but thee, and when thou art dead twill do, me little good— for I shall scarce out-live thee. So I am very indiffèrent, do▪ what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: No— come my Dear, I'll dispatch it now. Sir your pardon for a moment.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Prithee▪ let's withdraw and observe 'em a little.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Sir, He'll wait on you suddenly, in the mean time we leave the Ladies with you—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Your Servant: These I humbly conceive are Whores, or they wou'd not be here; how the Devil shall I talk to 'em both?

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Well— he's the prettiest Man that e're was born—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: You cannot have been long a Souldier, you are so young and smooth-fac'd—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I have no youth,— but what's at the Ladie's Service—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Pray what manner of Ladies have you beyond Sea?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Not half so pretty as the English Ladies.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: How do they make love there?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Faith Madam thus— we fall o' board as fast as we can, thus, and thus—
and thus and thus—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Hold, hold Sir, you are very brisk.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Well— he is a pretty good natur'd thing, I warrant him—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Have you been in many Battels? I see you are a valiant Man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Yes, many— I have been used to Fire, Smoak, and Cannon; Yells of Matrons, and groans of dying men, and cannot Boggle at a Lady; as for example—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: He is a gallant Officer, no doubt—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: You are a rare man▪ you think to storm a Lady, and carry her by Fire and Sword.
My time is but short, and I wish I were rid of her, that I might tell you how much I am taken with you; and if you would not believe my words, to show it by my actions—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: You flatter me. I am infinitely pleas'd with this Captain.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Captain, one word with you—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p:
Dear pretty Creature— how you transport me;
if yon Lady 〈◊〉 absent. I have such a passion to disclose to you.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: A most admirable man— Sir, I should be loath to be esteem'd ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What a condition we are in! S'heart— They'l ravish him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: These Wenches are stark mad after smooth-faced fighting fellows, let 'em be never such Puppies.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Dear pretty Rogue, y'are the sweetest Creature I ever saw, and she is disagreeable— oh that I had thee alone.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: You Compliment me, he's a fine bred man; what a mein he has?

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: By your leave. Sweet Captain, I believe you met with little resistance from the Ladies in Flanders.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I should be overjoy'd to meet none from thee, My dear pretty one, would yon Creature were away. I do not like her at all— I have that to tell you—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Are we not uncivil, both us to leave Madam Phillis— 〈◊〉 you will go to her, I'll come presently.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: I am not to be taught Civility from you, good Madam, go you—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Nor am I to be taught by you, and you go to that.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Very fine, they'l fight for him by and by.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: But Captain.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: I'll tell you Captain.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: 'Tis not good breeding, Madam, to interrupt one in speaking.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Tell me of breeding. There has been some difference in our breeding.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: That there has to my advantage: 'Slife your breeding.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: We are like to have very constant Mistresses, if we get 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: So— I am a very pretty fellow: I have got the hearts of both of 'em, and now I am afraid I shall find it hard to get rid of 'em.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: I wonder at your Impertinence.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: My Impertinence: You are a confident Creature.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Thou art below my anger.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Am I so? well— I know what you are▪

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Why! what am I Mrs. Minx?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Nay, good Ladies hold. Let this go no farther; for as I am an Officer, I am bound to secure you, faith—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: At your Command, good Captain— I shall desist—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: If it were not for your presence, sweet Captain, I should say more—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis time to appear. This young
fellow will have 'em both else.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What at Wars, Lady? You are a happy Man, Captain.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And a brisk one at Women, I see that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: So, so: We that come from the Camp are pretty well set, and are seldom over-bashful—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I see, Madam, you can be gracious to the Captain, though you are cruel to me.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: What because I shew a little outward Civility. Though really, he is the prettiest Gentleman I ever saw. But Captain, as we were saying—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Very fine.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I see you are most infinitely taken with the Captain: But I cannot get a good look of you—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Lord! that you should say so: Would not you have one well-bred to a stranger? But Captain, you were saying something to me even now—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is excellent— I see we must rout the Captain, or lose the Wenches.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Pox on all these whiffling young Officers! all the Whores run mad after 'em; and a good substantial solid Whoremaster cannot keep one in quiet for 'em▪

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Captain, your humble Servant— There's a Collation, and some Bottles waiting for you, and my Friends, and I beg your Company—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I will but see how my two new Souldiers are dispos'd of, and I'll wait on you. Do not stay for me, I beseech you—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Ladies! do you retire; there will be Drinking.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Your Servant, sweet Captain.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, good Captain—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: What shall I do amongst 'em; I cannot drink: yet I have a great Curiosity to see what it is that charms men to sit up whole Nights at eating Houses and Taverns.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p:
Sweet Captain, I have no time to stay, nor dare I be seen
alone with you; but That will tell you something, which I might blush to speak— Farewell—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Most excellent Women! what's this, another Conquest? hah—

That I was extreamly surpriz'd at the sight of you, This Paper will sufficiently prove; for could I have resisted your Charms, you had never seen it: But now I am afraid you have the pow'r to make me entirely Yours, Phillis.
What a Farce will this be when I am discover'd? Poor Wenches, how miserably I shall disappoint 'em—

div.stage: Enter Sir Humphrey, Bellamy, Wildman, Sir Christopher, Blunderbus, and Heildebrand. A Banquet. Table and Wine.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Come on, Sir Christopher! are you ready for a Bottle?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Ready! I warrant you! I have lain rough and recruited. I need less baiting for the Journey than a Carrier's Horse. Give me a Glass in my right hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Sit all—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Come faith, let's be all very merry, and roar extremely.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Take your course; Captain, your most humble Servant. Sir Christopher, this is the Captain you heard of.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: I honour him, and here's his Health in a Bumper—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Sir Humphrey, I must desire my Liberty. Wine does not agree with me, I never drink hard.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Every Gentleman is free in my House.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Hey! we shall have fine work indeed. What a Devil, a Captain, and cannot Drink? Can you Whore?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: So, so— well enough for a young Beginner.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Not Drink! 'Sheart! a man is not fit for a Captain that cannot Drink. Shall I ask you a question?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Can you Fight?

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Hold, good Sir Christopher, no Bullying here—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: You had best try, if you dare: Death! what a question was that! What Scoundrel art thou that askest such a question? This Company preserves thy life.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: I have done, I have done: 〈◊〉, He! he's damn'd stout, I believe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I could tell Thee Actions I have been in, would freeze thy blood to hear of! Fight— quoth a! Can'st thou fight up to the knees in blood? and at Midnight with no light but what Guns make, with Shot like hail about thy ears, clamber over mountains of dead Bodies, and fight thy way to a General's Tent, and bring the General Prisoner through all his Mirmidons? hah—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Sir, I beg your Pardon, I believe it. He's a plaguy stout fellow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: 'Tis not your best way to question it. Can you lead your Souldiers up to a wall, and scale it, when Bullets, melted Pitch and Sulphur rain upon you? Fight! the man ne'r lived that ask'd me yet that question!

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: 'Sheart, hee'l cut my Throat— Sir, I beg your Pardon, I say—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Come Captain, 'Tis enough: fall on upon this Collation, and we'll have a Chanson à boirè to compose the matter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Some Musick! Sing me a Song—

lg.l: LEt the daring Adventurers be toss'd on the Main,
And for Riches no dangers decline;
Though with hazard the spoils of both Indies they gain,
They 〈◊〉 bring us no Treasure like Wine.
Enough of such Wealth would a Beggar enrich,
And supply greater wants in a King;
'Twould sooth all the Griefs in a comfortless Wretch,
And inspire weeping Captives to Sing.
There is none that groans under a burdensom life,
If this soveraign Balsom he gains▪
This will make a man bear all the Plagues of a Wife,
And of Raggs, and Diseases in Chains.
It swells all our Veins with a kind purple flood,
And puts Love and great Thoughts in the mind:
There's no Peasant so rank, but it fills with good blood,
And to gallantry makes him inclin'd.
There's nothing our Hearts with such Joy can bewitch,
For on Earth 'tis a Pow'r that▪ s Divine;
Without it, we're wretched tho' never so Rich,
Nor is any man Poor that has Wine.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Pox! This is a pretty Musical business; but this will not make a man merry— I'll sing you a Song: Fill the Glasses first. Come on. When I sing Down, down, Then you must all drink—

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: I Love some body, I love no body,
Some body, no body dearly:
I love some body, &c.
Be she black, or be she brown,
She's the best in all the Town,
So she keep her Belly down.
Down, down, down down:
There's no fault to be found,
So she keep her Belly down.

sp.p: Hah! I think this is well, hah!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: A very merry fellow— Give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: I am your most humble Servant to command— I love a brave fellow with my heart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Come on, I have provided some Entertainment instead of a Dance— you shall see my two new Souldiers Exercis'd— fetch'em in Serjeant—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: You have found out an admirable way to plague an old cowardly Usurer, to make a Souldier of him—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I warrant I shall plague him e're I have done with him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: This is an excellent Trick found out for 'em.

div.stage: Enter Serjeant with Gripe and Richard.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Well, There's Law, Sir— yet— I say.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: 'Sheart, does he talk of Law agen? Knock him o'th'head.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I say no more—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Next Tide he takes Boat, and away for Flanders.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Oh! honest Gripe! Art thou turn'd Souldier? Thou art a good hopeful Musketeer of thy age.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: A very pretty old Fellow, and stands lustily under a Musket.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: A brave old Souldier, i'faith! Can'st thou stare a Cannon in the face?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: What's that to you, you Coxcombs— Well, I shall out-live this, Rogues; and all this may turn to my profit in the end.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Order your Arms—
Did you ever see such dull Rascals? order your arms thus, set 'em down— Take that to make you remember another time

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I must suffer! there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Poise your Muskets.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: What a Devil must we do now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Poise your Muskets thus, you Rascals— Pox on you for dull Rogues.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Well, so we do: What a Devil wou'd you have?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: What with both hands?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: In one hand, thus.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Well, thus then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Shoulder.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: That's the wrong shoulder—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: On the other shoulder! ye Blockheads, you have less sence than Statues—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Ay— I am so dull, you had better let me go—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I'll make you do it— Shoulder, I say. March.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I thank you Sir,— with all my heart— that— we will march—
sp.stage: They lay their Muskets down, and offer to go out.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: We'll march well enough, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Is that your marching? Take up your Arms, Rogues, I'll run you through else— take 'em up I say—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Well— well— what a Devil would you have? Did you not bid us march?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I'll make you march against the mouth of a Cannon, before I have done.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: O damn'd Tyrant, I must try to compound with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: This is admirable Discipline indeed, Captain.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Sir Christopher, Mr. Blunderbus and Heildebrand, take care, and shift for your selves. There are Threescore Bailiffs waiting for you in the Street, and they have beset the House round, that there is no possibility of escaping—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: O Heav'n! what shall I do? if I be once carried to Goal, I shall lye and rot there. Hold, let me see—

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: We shall starve if we go to Prison—

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Let us think of some way, They are too many for us to beat.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Captain, if you would but do us the favour to send for three Red Coats, and own us to be your Souldiers, we may escape.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: A rare way.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: An excellent way; good Captain favour us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: My Footmen have a Bundle of red Coats here; but I cannot in Honour pass you for my Souldiers, unless you be so— if you will take each a Shilling of me and be listed, you may▪ otherwise I can do you no good.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: There's 12 d. a peice, Serjeant take their Names— I shall order them too— I'll teach 'em to roar and bully up and down the Town. Get their Coats and Bandeleers on.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Come on Comrades, fellow Souldiers, give me your hands all— The more the merrier▪

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: How now saucy Rogue— Do you long very much for a broken— head—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: You may command all my House, and I beg of you to make it your own while you stay in England.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I give you humble thanks.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: So— how do these Accoutrements become us?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh rarely— you are the feircest Souldiers I have seen▪

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Now, noble Captain, we'll march under your Command.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: A Souldier must I be? Here's company for the Devil.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Come! we'll go into the Court-yard▪ There I'll exercise ye, and send for the Head-Bailiff, and let him know ye are my Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Very well, I vow, that will do rarely—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, in the mean time, we'll to the Women; your Servant, Captain.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Your Servant▪ Was ever design so well begun, and so hopefully carried on? They all take me for my Twin▪ Brother.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: I that know you both, don't wonder at it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Come Souldiers March— March, I say—

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: ACT. V.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: PRithee, Sir Humphrey, let▪ s not leave off our Debauch▪ but drink on: we have just wound our selves up, and tun'd our Instruments, and now we give over playing.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: 'Tis unreasonable— I would as soon turn my back upon a Woman I was in love with, just as I had gotten her consent, or run away when a Battel were first joyn'd, as leave my Bottle now.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: I do confess I am an Epicurean in this, and in every thing. I'd go no further than the pleasing of my Senses: I would have just so much Wine, as would give me an Appetite to Woman, and just so much Woman, as would give me a desire to Wine.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: After a Bottle and a half, the man that says Consider, is my Foe.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: This has but rais'd me—

lg.l: You only Court, and keep a pother
To make me Gamesome for another▪

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Faith Gentlemen▪ We have had the best of our selves; we have drawn off the Spirit, and nothing but the Lees remain.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We have but just kindled the fire and you would put it out.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Rather than that should put me out—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No; 'twill make our Souls burn clearer. Do but consider, that none but Fools are merry without Wine, such unthinking Coxcombs as are extreamly pleas'd with their own foolish persons.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But the thinking man comes to good 〈◊〉, and that pulls him back in the height of his Career, 〈◊〉 makes us think what frail Engines we are: But Wine makes us 〈◊〉 with the Coxcombs, merry and pleas'd with our selves.

sp.speaker: Sir 〈◊〉▪
sp.p: A man of sence is 〈◊〉, because he must make the best▪ I 〈◊〉 Market; but Fools are never truly pleas'd, they find themselves despis'd by those they really admire; for Wit is an Idol of all; and Fools only hate witty men, as a poor man does a rich one.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I know not whether they're pleas'd; but they laugh and make a noise, as if they were merry.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p:
So Children that are afraid of Spirits sing and make a noise in the dark, but are devillishly afraid for all that; and Coxcombs are damnably dull and sad for all their laughing; and even
when they drink, They have the Pain, but never the pleasure of Drunkenness.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A man would think Coxcombs the serenest Animals breathing; yet sure if they be happy, they are so for ought they know—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pox on 'em, let 'em be what they will: but nothing but Wine can make us merry; and therefore to our Celery again.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: We Northern people that want the Sun without, ought indeed to put good store of Wine, and create a Sun within us.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: That's right, to our Celery again, I say,

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: 'Tis pleasant while it is Flood within us; but we shall Ebb, and grow dull standing Water after a little while.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Prithee don't think to similize us out of our Bottles—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Nay, if you be resolv'd, you shall find me Coy no longer—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I knew he would▪ come to it at last: But thou art such a Jilting Drunkard—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Let's in then, if you will not, let me take the air a little.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Air! Open the Window▪ and take it that way—

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: I bring you News that will stop you in your Career of mirth— I can scarce tell it you for weeping.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: What means the fellow—

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: I little thought to live to see this day—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Pox o▪ your Formality! out with your dismal News—

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: All your Land in Essex is extended by your Creditors. And your Furniture the richest in the County all seiz'd upon.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: What says the 〈◊〉?—

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Would you had taken the Fool's counsel, it had not been so. I remember when my old Master purchas'd it, and little thought I should have seen it go out of the Family; and now there 〈◊〉 no remedy▪ for all the Land you had free, you have this day 〈◊〉 our Mistress— Whore.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: ▪ Sdeath is this true thou tellest me?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Too true, would Heav'n it were not; your Bailiff who is turn'd out of Possession, is come up with the News: And all this Money is run out to Rogues, from whom you have taken up Commodities upon Judgments; most of which you sold agen for half value—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: This is surprizing News! what a damp it has struck upon me— I begin to come to my self now.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: Many a good Christmas has my old Master kept there, and must it now be parted from his Family—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Gentlemen, my Friends— if you would oblige me so much as to be bound with me for a Sum of Money to stop these ravenous Creditors mouths for the present, I will sell my Timber, and redeem my House and Land afterwards, and secure you in the mean time.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How Sir! be Bound— hum— your Steward says, you have no Land to give Counter-Security with— I should be glad to serve you—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll venture my life for you, whenever you command me; but for being Bound you must excuse me. I have taken an Oath against that: besides, if I would, you cannot give Counter-Security—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: So! This is the world, I find; yet I could not have believ'd the Companions of all my Pleasures and Extravagancies could have thus deserted me— I thank you Gentlemen, for clearing my Understanding. 'Tis time to be Sober now: Well— I will try some sudden way; A desperate ill, must have a desperate cure— Farewel.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: So— What is become now of my Employment? 'tis not worth above six hours purchase. That I should live till now.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So here ends all our Revelling in this House: This is a sudden turn.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Beyond my expectation! what a Coxcomb he was to run out thus!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Indeed, I never thought he had much in him; he had but ordinary Sence at the best; but this was such a Folly, I am asham'd of him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: We must e'n leave his Company; but this Wench Celia runs in my mind. I must have her at any rate: tho' I keep—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am in the same condition; and if we do keep- we must watch 'em from young Officers; or they'l run devillishly astray else.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Whatever these Officers do abroad— I am sure they are always invading the Territories of the Keepers at home—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Tho' they are in a friends Countrey, they will make Excursions for forrage of that kind— But let us seek out these pretty Whores—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: 'Slife! what shall I do? these Wenches will over-run me.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Dear Captain, I must confess for all my Modesty, that I am transported at the Assurance which you give me of having your Love— I am not asham'd to say, You are the first that ever won my heart, and shall be the last to whom I e'r will give it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: And 'tis a Treasure I will never part with: Come seal the Promise with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: O! thou sweet Creature. I can deny thee nothing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: We are so vexed with that troublesome Creature, Chloris, who watches us.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: This House is large, and in the Evening! if you'l meet in the farther end of the long Gallery. There is a Room where we may discourse further of our Love.

sp.speaker: Mrs Gripe.
sp.p: Discourse! I hate Discourse, I am too vigorous for that— I shall so— kiss thee there—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Well! Thou art a pretty Rogue, I vow—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: How, kissing her!

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Yonder's that envious Creature: Farewel, at Eight in the Gallery—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Oh my dear sweet one, now that malicious Woman's gone, I can tell thee how I love thee.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Me! what did you kiss her for then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: The poor thing is so fond, she would kiss me; but I shall make such an Ass of her.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Nay! will you though, dear Captain?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Will I? why, I hate her Person and Conditions: Methinks she's ugly.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Indeed, I think she is not handsom, that's the short and the long on't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Handsom! Thou art an Angel to her! Oh how I love thy Beauty and thy Shape—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Nay! be quiet now— I vow you make me blush—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Oh dear Rogue! That I were in bed with Thee and the Candles out, and blush what thou could'st.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Well, I cannot help telling of you, you are the prettiest Man I ever saw.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Thou know'st not half that's in me! we are watch't now— But meet me at the farther end of the long Gallery this Night at Eight, and you shall find me a Lion—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: And you would have me your Lamb then. Well, I'll meet and venture— Here comes Madam Phillis— Farewel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Here's another! No Mortal Captain could tell what to do with these Three: (As gad save me) 'tis unreasonable.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Sweet Captain, I have blush't sufficiently at the little Billet I gave you; I scarce have Confidence enough to see you after it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Dear fair one, If you had not resolv'd to see me, your Letter had been in vain; if I could tell you my Transport at the reading of it, I should be more Eloquent than Sir Formal himself▪

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Can you forgive my Confidence?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I am sure 'tis so much to my advantage, that I should never have forgiven your Bashful●…ulness.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: This is excess of Generosity.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Bashfulness in Love! you prevented me, or you shou'd have seen I was not bashful.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: But that I fear'd your sudden Departure for Flanders, you should have learn't my Love from other Signs—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Depart for Flanders! while my dear Mrs. is here! It cannot be; I'll this Night give up my Commission.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: My Dear! you are not sure in earnest?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Upon my Honour, Madam— I am. Sir Humphrey has made me promise him to lye here this Night: My Chamber is at the farther end of the Gallery, at Eight if you'l meet me there, I'll shew you I am in earnest; by this Kiss I will!

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Sure there's Witchcraft in you, that you should charm me thus.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I confess 'tis ungrateful, Sir Humphrey has so oblig'd me—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Ne'r think on that; who shall tell him? I fear we are watch't— Farewel— at Eight—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Good constant Turtles these kept Ladies are, I▪ ll say that for 'em: And good charitable publick spirited men the Keepers to maintain women, as they wear Perfumes for the use of others—
Oh Serjeant! what effect of your Negotiation with my Husband?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Very little; for when I told him my Captain's Proposals to have the 3000 l. his Sister brought, paid back, or 400 l. a year seperate maintenance, be started, stamp'd and star'd like a man distracted: He bid me knock him on the head, shoot him— cut his Throat, or what I would— I had better do it, then give him such Words—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Indeed that was very ill language to give him.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: I told him at last, there was no other Composition to be made, but he must this Tide for Flanders; and you would take all the care that could be to put him upon such desperate Actions as might bring him to be knock't o'th' head, and that if he did not meet death that way, he should be sure to have it from my Captain's hand, for the Injuries he had done his Sister: I left him Cursing, and in Despair.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: 'Tis a great question whether he had rather dye, or part with the Money: But I'll try one Experiment more, and if I cannot get it by Stratagem, away he goes with my Brother to Flanders: And my last refuge shall be open Force, I'll e'n take possession of his Writings, and rob him: I'll exercise him first, and swinge my Bullies too. Have you a File of Musqueteers ready in case of Resistance?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Come on—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: I have found you out, to confer with you about something that concerns our Honour, and our Love.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: And I am to tell you of something that concerns my Honour, and your want of Love.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: How Madam?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Do you think I am to be valu'd at the rate of the ordinary ill-bred kept things of the Town.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I have not valued you so! What does she mean?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: You must know Sir— I look upon my self to be in a manner your Lady—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Very well— I have been a fine Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: And do you imagine that I, who am in a manner your Lady will suffer such Debauchery and Wickedness in my House?

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: How long has it been your House?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Since yesterday; and 'tis as much mine, as if it had descended from my Ancestors these 500 years.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: To whose bounty do you owe it?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: To no bounty; I owe it to my own Beauty, and those Charms that made you settle it on me, and my Faith and Constancy has deserv'd it fully—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Most excellent!

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Shall I throw away the flow'r of all my youth, and resist all the temptations of the fine Gentlemen about the Town, without those usual Settlements which Ladies of my Condition have: In short, I am to let you know 'tis my House, and I will have no Abominations committed here! it goes against my Conscience.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: So— I have parted with most part of my Estate, and Liberty to boot! Oh negligence, and want of thinking.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: To have you and your lewd Companions Sotting and Drinking, and using all Licentiousness. But above all, to have Whores brought into my House too! such filthy Creatures, whom you know I hate with all my heart▪ it melts me into tears to think on't—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Be mollify'd, good Madam; I hope the Sin you speak of is not so great; for your sake—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Do you think I will dishonour my self any longer, to suffer those little ill-bred Kept-things, Celia and Chloris, to come to my House? No! your Sisters and your Mother shall be welcom to me; provided they give me that respect which is due to me: I intend to visit and keep Company with none but Persons of Quality—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Pray Madam, who is it that has kept you?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: My Beauty, and my Merit; not your Bounty—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: And are not you a Tailor's Daughter?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: My Fortune makes me of a good Family, and you must know, Sir— I have been kept so long, that I look upon my self as your Lady now.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: See the damn'd Insolence and Unreasonableness of these Creatures call'd Whores; if a man keeps 'em from starving one year, they'd plague a man ever after. If I mistake not, you have told me that you lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Yes, till your wicked Courses have provok'd me beyond all measure! and therefore pray consider of it, and give me an answer, if you resolve to persist— pray quit my House. Farewel—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: O damn'd Whore! I have a way to circumvent thee though: I must plague my self to punish Thee—

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Gripe, Serjeant, Gripe, Richard, Sir Christopher, Heildebrand and Blunderbus.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Come! Where are my Souldiers? I must lose no time, but exercise you often; for we shall enter upon Action as soon as we come in Flanders—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I am not for Flanders, nor any Action; but Actions upon the Case.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Heart! does he mutter? Tye him neck and heels quickly—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Hold, hold— you'l stifle me. I am so stiff I cannot bend. Hold, I say, I will obey.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Come Captain, you have done enough with us; now you have own'd us before the Bailiffs. Let us go, we'll go to the Temple or Alsacia for refuge till the Business be over.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Good Bully Captain, you over-acted your Part, and laid on too hard before the Bailiffs tho'— let me tell you that.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: You broke my head; I do not use to put it up, but upon this occasion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I must keep strict Discipline amongst my Souldiers, you shall find that was nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, let that pass; but now Captain, let's be in earnest, and go you along and sup with us in White-Fryers, we'll have Fiddles and Whores to entertain you, and roar like Dragons, and be as merry and as mad as Lightning.

lg.l: Be she black▪ or be she brown,
She's the best in all the Town.

sp.p: How now, old Fool? How do you like a Souldier's life?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, no fooling; you have receiv'd the King's Money, and his Cloaths, and I will make you know you are my Souldiers— Stand to your Arms all!

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Hah— What a Devil does he say?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Handle your Arms, all: Dam'me! what am I disobey'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: 'Sheart! my Head and Shoulders! prithee Captain leave fooling. What a Devil, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Death! Handle your Arms all— I'll make you know your Officer.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Ounds! if you strike agen, I'll draw—

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Out comes Porker, if you strike once more.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Prithee Captain leave off, you have carried on the Frollick long enough.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Nay then have at you! Musqueteers make ready.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Make ready? ha! what a Devil do you mean?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Present.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Hold! hold! I'll obey.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Hold, hold— we'll obey.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Hold, hold— we'll obey.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: 'Sdeath you Dogs▪ no trifling with me! shall such Rascals as you think it enough to be Drunk, and Swagger, beat Bawds, kick Drawers, squabble with Constables and Watches, break Windows, and triumph in Drunken Brawls and Street-quarrels, and never serve your Countrey?— If you have Valour, I ll make you turn it that way.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Good Captain, we did not think you would have us'd us thus! we did not intend to be Soldiers; we only desir'd to be protected by you— for this present Occasion—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: What e'r you intended, my Company is not compleat, and I'll make you know you are the King's Soldiers now— I shall protect no Rascally Poultroons— if any thing can do't— do bravely, and your valour may defend you; Death! shall such idle lazy Scoundrels bully, and roar and boast of drunken bloodless quarrels here at Home— While we lye hard, suffer weary marches, and fight all in blood, for our Country abroad, hah!—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Very fine! we have brought our selves into a pretty Condition.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Pox on your Project, we had as good have been in the Bailiffs hands.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: This damn'd Captain— has ten Bullies in him—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Who the Devil— would have thought it? a little pitiful fellow— I thought I could have beaten two of him—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Ground your Arms.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Thank you, good Captain, with all my heart; shaw! Pox I knew he did this but to try us. Come, all's well now—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Tye 'em neck and heels instantly.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Nay, prithee Captain don't fool with us any more now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Serjeant, see it done.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: You shall find 'tis no fooling—
sp.stage: He with the Musqueteers. tye them neck and heels.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Why Captain, what a Devil?

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: What a Pox!

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Is the Devil in you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: This is for example: Next mutiny I'll hang ye!

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Now Rogues and Bullies, why don't you sing and roar now? How do you like Soldiers lives now?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Why look you, Comrades, This 'tis to want experience in your Duty! you must learn to ride the wooden▪ Horse, once or twice a day too.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Why Captain— good Captain.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Captain, Zounds, Captain.

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Why Captain— Death and Heart—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: No remorse yet! What you old Villain, you are resolv'd not to do my Sister Right, and return her Portion, or settle her Jointure on her presently—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Ounds! part with 3000 l. I had rather dye.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: And that by Heav'n thou shalt do; nay more, she shall take possession of thy Writings, thy Money, and thy Pawns; and satisfie her self.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: How's that? That's worst of all—

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Oh Gentlemen! where are you? you are turn'd Soldiers, I hear: you have almost kill'd me amongst you, and won my Money, a deuce take ye! My Celia will be dreadful angry, I am afraid.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Rogue! we shall meet you.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: I am glad to see you in this Condition, now one may safely keep you Company.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: How now Sirrah! who are you? a Soldier in no condition is to be laught at, by such an Insect, a Maggot as thou art.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: A Maggot! an Insect— I am a Knight, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: You are a Rascal, Sir! take that—

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Nay! I have done, Captain,— if you be angry, I beg your Pardon, I am going to find out my Mistress, Farewell, Sir— I am sure they have made me cruel Sick, a poise take 'em.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: Good Captain, let us be unty'd! we'll obey—

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Good Captain, let us be unty'd! we'll obey—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Prithee dear Captain do— I will be correspondent to command, and be a gentle Spirit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Unty 'em—
This is call▪ d a Receipt to tame a Bully— I shall show you there's more than roaring goes to true Valour: Come, Handle your Arms—
Poise your Musquets— awkard Rascals!
Shoulder all— Now, Puppy, the wrong shoulder, Sot. [To Sir Chr. Rest your Arms.
To the Right— Now old fool, can you not tell your right hand from your left yet?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: What will become of me? I cannot bear this! Heav'n deliver me from this damn'd Tyrant; my Wife will rob me too, that's worst of all—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: You are the strangestawkard old Fellow, Comrade, that ever I saw— learn of me—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: To the right! to the right! now Rascal you are to the left.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Well, well— what a Devil would you have?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: To the left, to the left! so, so— Now march— very well— you will come on I see in time— Serjeant, March 'em to their Quarters here in this House; and set a Sentinel over every one of'em.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: I will Captain. Come march—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I do not find that this old Fellow mollifies at all; yet I'll try one Experiment more upon him, and if he relents not, my Brother carries him in earnest.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: 'Tis Eight a clock, sure the Captain's come by this time! I hope I have not made him stay— 'Tis very dark—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: It has struck Eight, where is this dear, sweet Captain— I hope he is punctual to his assignation—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Ha— I hear a noise of some body— who's there?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: 'Tis I, my Dear!

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Where are you?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Here! Give me yourhand—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Oh my sweet Captain. Both together.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Dear, dear Captain. Both together.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Ha! who's this, a Woman?

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Heav'n what's this, a Gown and Petticoat?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Mercy upon me, who are you?

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: What's that to you, I will not'tell you, a malicious Slut, to watch me and spoil my Assignation—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Oh! Thou poor envious Fool, Thou expect to meet the Captain, I know thee— Vengeance on this Fool—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Yes! and so do I you; and wonder you should be such a Fool to expect the Captain: He meet such a one as Thee?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: This is the place and time of meeting, now for my pretty dear Captain.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Thee! poor inconsiderable Creature! He laughs at Thee to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Did he tell you so?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Yes, he did— he scorns Thee for thy Folly, and loaths Thee for thy Person.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Thou bely'st him! He scorns thy words! my Person! 'tis an other— guess Person than thine: I'd have thee to know I am sure he hates Thee.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: 'Slife I have scap'd a fine discovery of my self to these two Wenches. They are my Rivals, and are quarreling for the Captain here.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: I wonder at thy Confidence, to think the Captain should meet thee! He appointed me to meet him at this time here, about a little Business—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: A little Business— I know your Business— but he has no such Intention— prithee Impudence begon, he appointed me to meet him here, where I was to confer with him, without being troubled with Thee—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: You confer!

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: What say They— This must be false— They are conceited! Vain Sluts! I am sure he would meet none but me— I'll rout 'em out of my House, I am sure—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: If I could see thee, I'd pull thy eyes out—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Fool begon— I laugh at Thee.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: How shall I send 'em away, and get the Captain to my Self?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: I hear some body! Who's there— Captain— my Dear!

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Thy Dear— here am I, Captain.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: I am the Devil come to meet you both—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Oh Lord.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Help—

div.stage: Enter Sir Humphrey, with a Candle, and a Parson with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: How now! what's the matter here?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Oh unlucky time! must he come too! Nothing my Dear, but I play'd the Rogue, and frighted these two in the dark.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Am I discover'd to her— oh mischief—

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Must she over-hear me. I could have born the other down, if she had Spoken of it—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Since you are grown so pious— I have brought a Learned Churchman to confer with you about a Case of Conscience, I have been in every Room in the House to find you out, pray come along with me—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: I obey.

div.stage: Enter Gripe and Richard, Mrs. Gripe in Womans habit, a Manteau, a Petticoat, and a Hood.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Oh Heav'n and Earth! is the perfidious Jade my Wife here? were ever two so like in Face and Nature, as these accurs'd Twins—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: My Dear, look not so strangely on me— for I am sadly sensible of my own rashness, and your great Injuries from my cruel Brother.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: What's the meaning of this— I will, if possible, make use of her to get my liberty, and if I can get her home to me, I'll murder her—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I am come full of Sorrow and Repentance, having been at my Brother's Lodging ever since the moment of my Escape; and not hearing of your usage till now— if you will pardon me, I will propound some means for your Liberty, and go home and submit wholly to your pleasure—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: My dearest Wife! now thou art thy self agen— I shall be transported to receive thee into my Arms.
I think strangling will be a very good Death— for her as can be—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Can'st thou forgive me, Dearest?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: O yes, my Dear, and love thee as well as e'r I did— Or if I should run her through with my Sword, and say she kill'd her self—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I would go for my Lord Chief Justices Warrant, and raise the Town, but I'd release Thee; but my rash Brother knowing what my Conjugal affections would prompt me to, when I came to sollicit for your Liberty, he put me under the hands of his Serjeant, and I am as much confin'd as you: The time grows short, and we must think of some sudden way to prevent your Voyage—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Dear heart! I can never reward thee enough for thy kindness to me— if we get home again together, thou shalt be as free as thou can'st wish to be—
Let me see, a small knitting Needle under her left Arm when she's asleep▪ will do the business rarely—
What can'st thou propound for me to do? my dearest Heart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: There's no way left, but to seem to comply with him; for he is resolutely bent—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Comply! what to go for Flanders?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: No— in that Settlement he proposes for me.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Mercy on me! What 3000 l. or 400 l. a year separate Maintenance! oh— I shall faint! y have struck me dead. 'Sheart! what a Sum is that?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I have a small Brandy-Bottle, '●is Soldier-like, and very Comfortable.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: 'Tis nothing in thy Wealth.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Nothing! Damnation! knock me o'th head, or cut my Throat— If I should smother her with a Bolster, and give out she dy'd of an Apoplexj! that's the most secret way I have thought on yet.
If you love me, why did you not refuse that settlement?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I did, and told him I would not accept on't! at which he was enrag'd, and told me, though I was a Fool for my self, he would not be so for me; he was resolv'd you should do it, or suffer the last extremity; and he's so inflam'd, he may for ought I know throw thee overboard in the Voyage, if thou refusest.

sp.speaker: Gripe▪
sp.p: Let him do't: Ounds, 3000 l. or 400 l. a year! let him do't, let him do't, let him do't, I say.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Why my Dear! if thou sign'st that Deed, I'll return it thee again. And be thy most obedient Wife.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Poor Rogue! wilt thou? that's kind indeed; prithee kiss me, my pretty Dear: Thou overjoy'st me with thy Love!

Hah— I have thought on the best way, if I can get her home with me, I'll give her Opium in her drink, and that ne'r a Doctor or Chyrurgeon on 'em all can discover, when they open her. Ay, it shall be so!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: The least thing I could hear him propound, was to seize upon thy Jewels and thy Deeds, and secure 'em in a Friend's hands of his, till he had reduc'd you to comply.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: O Devil! that's worst of all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Trust me, we are one flesh, our interests are one: I shall restore Thy Deed, and be subject; for my Conscience will not let me part from Thee, tho' the rashness of my passion made me fly.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Poor Lamb! if I had thee sase at home, I'd ne'r give thee Occasion more: prithee go to thy damn'd Brother, and try to mollifie him farther, while I retire and consider of this.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I will, my Dear— one kiss first.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis a Dear Soul!
Well, she takes Opium, that's certain; for while she lives, I shall never be at rest from this Devillish Rascal her Brother.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Go into your Quarter! come Madam—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If you don't sind me as obsequious, and as kind a Keeper as the best of 'em—

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: I must confess you speak reasonably, and like a Gentleman. But I shall break Sir 〈◊〉 's heart—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You have broken his Fortune, and when that's gone, 'tis no matter for his heart.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: That indeed is undeniable, and I can no longer resist those Charms which before subdu'd me.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: I must confess you speak so like a worthy person, and shew such signs of Love to me, that I cannot but think you the finest person in the world; but Sir Christopher will kill me if I should leave him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Let me alone to defend the heart I gain: Besides, he's undon! a beggarly fellow, and is going a Redcoat into Flanders.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Indeed he has been extravagant, and run out a great part of his Estate; and I hate a man that has run out his Fortune: I vow I do, with my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Ah my Dear, art thou there? I am come at last to thee, pretty one.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Get you gon, you drunken Sot; you were drunk with Bullies, and lost your Watch and Ring.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Why look you there, I thought what 'twould come to: As I hope to be sav'd I could not help it; They would have kill'd me if I had not drank and play'd with them, and I knew you would have been very angry, if I had been kill'd.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Get you gone, you impertinent Coxcomb! must you come and interrupt me, when I am talking with a Gentleman; have you no breeding?

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Well, well, say no more. I'll stand by▪ and wait till you have done.

div.stage: Enter Sir Humphrey, Phillis, Parson and Steward.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Call in all my Servants. Now all this Company take notice, I am married to this Lady— Here's the Canonical Officer that executed us.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: I did Marry 'em as the Church appoints.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How Married!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: To his Wench?

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you seem to wonder at my proceeding! I found my self involv'd on a sudden, beyond any other redemption, and therefore chose this, which I hope will set me free. This shepyrat had rob'd me of what my extravagance had left free, and I have taken Letters of Reprisal, and have gotten my own agen.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I wish you Joy.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Much happiness to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: She is the greatest Fortune I could have gotten, nor do I know why a Man should not fit a Woman that perhaps may last him his life time, and yet draw on a Shoe that he is to wear but two days before he take it.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: I wish your Ladiship much Joy; 'tis a great honour to our Function to have one of it so advanced.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: I wish your Ladiship much Happiness— but there's no Wife lives like one of us— let me tell her that.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Gripe, Serjeant, Gripe, Sir Christopher, Blunderbus and Heildebrand.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Sir Humphrey, I have sudden Orders from the General to Embark this Tide with my Soldiers; I came hearing of your Marriage, to wish you joy, and take my leave of you—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: Sir, I humbly thank you, and wish you a good Voyage.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Now I desire all this good Company to be Witnesses to the Agreement made between me, and this Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: What a Pox does he say?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: It is agreed by and between the Parties above mention'd, that I am to have the sole use of this Ladies Person, to my own proper behoof, paying the Sum of 400 l. a year, and buying a pretty convenient Coach and Horses: what say you?

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: It is a bargain.

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Oh damn'd confounded Jade, wilt thou leave me?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Good words Red-Coat, or I'll cut your Throat.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: You are going for a Soldier, and leaving me.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Ay! you are going for a Soldier! what would you have her do? I warrant you won't take my Celia at this; I'll trust her pretty Rogue—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: You damn'd Impudent Rascal! must you prate? Sirrah! take that.
