sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Ay! 'tis no matter, I han't lost my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now hear us a little: Item, It is articled and agreed between this Lady and me, that I am to use, possess and enjoy the Tenement of of her Person without any lett, hinderance, or molestation whatsoever, buying a Coach and Horses, as aforesaid; and paying the annual Rent of 400 l. per annum, of lawful Money of England; half yearly by true and equal portions▪ The first payment to be made at the Temple-Hall, at the Feast of the Annunciation, and the next at the Feast of St. Michael.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Hold Sir! not so fast, I forbid the Banes! she's mine! why I have spent half my Estate upon her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Stand away, poor Coxcomb! what say you Madam.

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: It is a Match.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: O Lord! Oh Lord! will you serve me so? what will become of me?

sp.speaker: Celia.
sp.p: Go! get you home, and live civilly with your Wife; and look after your Children as an honest man should. 'Tis time.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Ay— It may thank you that I did not do it before, that it may— I will go hide my head in a hole, and ne'r be seen again.
sp.stage: Enter Mrs. Gripe, Serjeant, Gripe, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Come Serjeant! get the Barge ready.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: What a Devil shall I do? If I Seal that Deed, and ever get her into my Custody, I'll have it again, and her life to boot.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Gentlemen and Ladies, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Hold, hold— If there be no remedy, I will Seal that Deed—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Come on then! do it, and I'll release you.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I deliver this as my Act and Deed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Now Gentlemen, be pleas'd to witness it—

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: With all my heart—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: So! Now there remains another thing! you must release these Gentlemen for their Riot at your House, or go still.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Well— I do release 'em.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Good Sir! do not release me; for I must go home and starve with him— I had better go and be kill'd with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: No— I retain you as my Servant. And now good Mr. Gripe, your much abus'd Wife is free, and thanks you for her Liberty.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: O Devil! Is it she all this while?

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.p: A Woman!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Yes Ladies, I am; but wish my self a Man, for your sakes, and my own.

sp.speaker: Sir Humph.
sp.p: How this Mistake was carried?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: I'll bring my Brother to thank▪ you for your favours to me, and then you'l Mistake as much.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Am I thus Cozen'd— I'll go home, and starve to Death. The Devil take you all— and so farewel—

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: Cudgel'd and beaten thus damnably by a Woman! I hope She Captain, you will release us now—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Yes go— I'll have no Bullies in my Company now.

sp.speaker: Blund.
sp.p: 'Sheart! were ever men so dishonour'd as we!

sp.speaker: Heild.
sp.p: Beaten and bruis'd by a Woman!

sp.speaker: Sir Chr.
sp.p: As for that damn'd Jade, I will scowr and break her Windows every night in the year.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Gripe.
sp.p: Now all ye Husbands, let me Warn ye!

lg.l: If you'd preserve your Honours, or your Lives;
Ne'r dare be Tyrants o're your Lawful Wives.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.stage: Spoken by Mrs. Barrey, who acted the Woman-Captain.

lg.l: WHo dares deny the Poet his applause
When I am Champion, and assert his cause?
Let him be Bully, ne'r so stout and tall,
'Sdeath I'll not fear the briskest of ye all:
No, though ye Rant and Roar, and sometimes Fight,
I've that which never fails to do me right.
Your would-be Wits love what is slight and bright
In Tinsel-wit, just like their own delight,
And Plays like Birth-day Suits, made for a Night,
These are o'rejoy'd to have a jest at hand
That costs but little Wit to understand.
Good sence, like solid Meat to sickly Men,
As soon as swallowed, is thrown up agen;
And for strong Meats, but few of ye are fit,
Who to meet Wit, should come with equal Wit,
And faith of late, that's but thin sown i'th' Pit.
He found by▪ s last, you would not like what's good,
Though it was praised by all that understood.
Remembring how you used that last he writ,
He made this Low, so to your Level sit;
Plenty of Noise, and scarcity of Wit—
The Devil's in you all, if this don't hit:
Yet after all, if any one there be
So careless of his Life to anger me,
In daring to dispraise the Play, or Action,
There take my Glove, for I ll have Satisfaction.
